Interestingly while video games often get a bad rap when it comes to talking dopamine. For me it is one of the things that has helped me nurture a growth mindset. I suppose it depends a lot on what types of games you play but I can definitely contribute my ability to find pleasure in the challenge, the grind and the struggle to video games. With that said since I also get a dopamine release from playing games as it is something I enjoy I have implemented the casino effect into how I play games. I basically randomize how much I'm allowed to play on a given day. And that's it. A slight touch of slot-machine and we'll see how that affects my enjoyment of this hobby.

As summarized by an ai: ### The Ultimate Guide to Dopamine: How to Master Motivation, Drive & Focus  Dopamine is one of the most discussed molecules in modern wellness, often misunderstood as simply the chemical of pleasure or a "dopamine hit" we get from rewards. The reality is far more nuanced. Dopamine is the fundamental driver of our motivation, desire, and cravingâ€”the force that propels you to pursue goals, from getting a cup of coffee to earning a degree.  Understanding how to manage your dopamine system is critical for sustaining long-term energy, focus, and satisfaction. This guide breaks down the science of dopamine and provides actionable tools to harness its power for a more motivated and fulfilling life.  #### The Core Principle: Baseline vs. Peaks  If you remember nothing else, remember this: your dopamine system operates on two levels.  1.  *Tonic (Baseline) Dopamine:* This is the steady, low-level amount of dopamine that is always circulating in your brain. It dictates your general mood, energy, and motivation on a day-to-day basis. 2.  *Phasic (Peak) Dopamine:* These are the large, rapid spikes of dopamine released in response to rewarding or exciting activities and substances.  Crucially, these two levels are interconnected. *After you experience a high peak in dopamine, your baseline level temporarily drops below its original point.* The higher the peak, the deeper the subsequent crash. This is the biological basis of the "pleasure-pain balance." That feeling of wanting more, or feeling a little down after a big win or an indulgent experience, is the result of your baseline dopamine falling.  Chasing constant high-dopamine peaksâ€”whether from food, social media, drugs, or even work achievementsâ€”steadily erodes your baseline. Over time, you require more stimulation to feel pleasure, and the things that once brought you joy feel less rewarding. Addiction is the extreme form of this cycle: a progressive narrowing of the things that bring you pleasure.  #### What Really Increases Dopamine? A Comparative Look  Different activities cause different levels of dopamine increase over your baseline. Here are some measured examples:  *   *Chocolate:* 1.5x increase above baseline *   *Sex:* 2x increase *   *Exercise (if enjoyed):* 2x increase *   *Nicotine (smoked):* 2.5x increase *   *Cocaine:* 2.5x increase *   *Amphetamine:* 10x increase  It's important to note that your subjective experience matters. If you assign positive meaning to an activity, like learning to enjoy the effort of exercise, you can increase the dopamine it provides.  #### Strategies for Healthy Dopamine Management  The goal is not to eliminate dopamine peaks but to manage them intelligently to protect your baseline and sustain motivation.  *1. Stop Layering Your Dopamine Sources*  It's common to "stack" multiple sources of dopamine to maximize pleasureâ€”listening to your favorite music while having a pre-workout drink before a gym session you enjoy. While effective in the short term, this practice teaches your brain that it needs all those conditions to feel motivated.  *Tool:* To maintain enjoyment in an activity, intentionally engage in it without the extra dopamine layers sometimes. For example, work out without music occasionally. This prevents your brain from becoming dependent on a specific cocktail of rewards and keeps your motivation robust.  *2. Reward the Effort, Not the Outcome*  A classic experiment showed that children who were rewarded for drawingâ€”an activity they already enjoyedâ€”stopped drawing once the reward was removed. When you reward yourself only for the final achievement (the grade, the finish line, the paycheck), you teach your brain that the effort itself is purely a cost. This makes the process more difficult and undermines intrinsic motivation.  *Tool:* Learn to generate dopamine from the effort itself. During a difficult task, consciously acknowledge the friction and tell yourself, "This is hard, and I'm doing it by choice. This effort is the reward." This is the essence of a "growth mindset." By finding pleasure in the struggle, you make the process itself rewarding and build a resilient, self-sustaining motivation system.  *3. Embrace Intermittent Reinforcement*  The most powerful motivator is an unpredictable reward schedule. Itâ€™s the mechanism that makes gambling and social media so addictive. You never know when the reward will come, so you keep trying.  *Tool:* Apply this to your own life. Don't always reward yourself for a given activity. For example, before a workout, flip a coin. Heads, you listen to music; tails, you don't. This randomness prevents your dopamine circuits from expecting and depending on a consistent reward, which keeps your motivation high over the long term.  *4. Use Cold Exposure for a Sustained Rise*  One of the most powerful, non-pharmacological ways to influence dopamine is through deliberate cold exposure. A study in the European Journal of Physiology found that immersing the body in cold water (e.g., 60Â°F / 14Â°C) caused a *250% increase in baseline dopamine.*  Unlike the sharp rise and fall from other stimulants, this increase was sustained, taking up to three hours to return to normal. This explains the lasting feeling of elevated mood, calm, and alertness that many people report after an ice bath or cold shower.  #### Supplements and Compounds that Influence Dopamine  While behavioral tools are paramount, certain compounds can directly affect the dopamine pathway. Use them with a clear understanding of their effects.  *For Boosting Dopamine:*  *   *L-Tyrosine:* An amino acid precursor to dopamine. Taken in doses of 500-1000 mg, it can increase focus and motivation for a short period (30-60 minutes), but may lead to a subsequent crash. Best used sparingly. *   *Macuna Pruriens:* A bean that naturally contains L-DOPA, the direct precursor to dopamine. It causes a very powerful and rapid increase in dopamine, but also a significant crash. Due to its potency, it should be approached with extreme caution. *   *Caffeine:* While its direct effect on dopamine is modest, regular caffeine intake has been shown to upregulate dopamine receptors, making your brain more sensitive to the dopamine you already have. Yerba MatÃ©, in particular, may have neuroprotective properties for dopamine neurons.  *Compounds to Be Cautious With:*  *   *Melatonin:* Supplementing with melatonin has been shown to decrease dopamine levels. Itâ€™s best to avoid it unless treating jet lag. *   *High-Potency Stimulants (e.g., Adderall, Cocaine):* These drugs cause such massive dopamine peaks that they can be neurotoxic over time and have been shown to limit the brain's ability to learn and change (neuroplasticity).  #### The Social Side of Dopamine  Finally, don't underestimate the power of social connection. Research shows that oxytocinâ€”the "bonding" hormoneâ€”directly stimulates the brain's dopamine pathways. Pursuing and engaging in healthy, meaningful relationships is a natural and essential way to keep your dopamine system active and healthy.  By understanding that dopamine is a currency to be managed, not just a pleasure to be chased, you can take control of your motivation, focus, and overall well-being. The key is to protect your baseline, find reward in effort, and use peaks strategically to fuel a life of sustained drive and satisfaction.

Thank you for this life changing video.  Here are my thoughts.  1. How do you think the mind's constant pursuit of dopamine can lead to a sense of dissatisfaction or unhappiness, even when we're achieving our goals or acquiring things we think will bring us pleasure?  Because dopamine has a peak and baseline. The peak is what we experience when we just start something new, and the baseline is how we feel when the peak declines and we are so used to that thing..reason for wanting more and more, and unsatisfaction regardless of our wealth.  2. How do you think the mind's tendency to constantly seek dopamine can impact our relationships and interactions with others?  Well, yes it does impact. At the beginning of our relationship we explore new things together, giving each of us a sense of love and unity..but over time, those little things we do to boost love wears off and we are faced with the truth of who we are in our being.  3. How can we cultivate a more mindful and authentic approach to relationships, one that's less dependent on dopamine peaks and more focused on genuine connection and understanding?  Simply by accepting what is for what is, rather than seeking something differently.. all of which would be impossible to do from the mind, it is the mind that wants to grasp, understand and all, so the moment we learn to be with this thoughts without reacting to it, it becomes easy. The point is not that we won't do things with our partners, the point is that, we won't depend on this for our growth, reward for increase in love and many more.  4. How can we balance the need for mindfulness and non-attachment with the natural human desire for intimacy, connection, and shared experiences with our partner?  It's the mind that wants to understand, which it can never do. There is no balance rather, simply just learn how to be with your minds.  5. How do you think this understanding can impact our daily lives, beyond just relationships, in areas like work, creativity, and overall well-being?  Therein lies what we all seek..peace. pure being, no suffering.  (This is a summary of the video, I asked AI to ask me questions and gave answers to it, hopefully it helps someone out there)

He keeps talking and talking like everything he says is a fact without giving us some type of proof or some experiments to back it up.30 minutes in and he only gave us ONE experiments with the cold water.If you only learn about such topics through books and you come across his video,his video feels shallow.Even the concept of neuroplasticity wasnâ€™t taken seriously by scientists until a few years ago.GIVE US SOMETHING TO BACK UP YOUR OPINIONS

- Your experience of life and levels of motivation and drive depends on how much dopamine you had relative to your recent experience. How much dopamine you experience from something depends on your baseline level of dopamine when you arrive there and your preivous dopamine peaks. thats why when you repeatedly do something you enjoy your threshold for enjoyment goes up and up and up - if you think or journal about aspects of a task/item that you enjoy or appreciate you can evoke dopamine from doing that task. Caution against saying things like I hate working but i love the reward i get afterward. Rewards given afterward actually make the situation worse. they wont make you like working more but actually undermine the dopamine release that would otherwise occur for that activity. - layering together multiple things, substances, activities that lead to big increases in dopamine can lead to pretty servere issues with motivation an energy with dopamine even a few days later. if you do it too often your level of motivation and drive will take a serious hit. - after a big peak in dopamine example: celebrating winning a marathon, the peak is folllow by a drop below baseline. and the drop is relative to how high the peak was. that is why when we do something over and over again that we like to do it feels less and less exciting. - theres a pleasure pain balance of dopamine spikes. the pain is felt as wanting more dopamine from it. - there is a limited amount of dopamine made in your brain. when you take something that has a massive spike in dopamine afterward your baseline drops because there isnt any dopamine left to keep your brain going.  59:50 then when you take it again to get the spike again your baseline keeps lowering and lowering. this is addiction. - to replenish the dopaminerigic pool in your brain avoid activites that evoke dopamine to bring your brain back to baseline - intermitten scheduling of dopamine is the key - try not to celebrate a win too hard unless you are willing to experience the drop in dopamine after - dont layer in sources of dopamine before doing a task. - if you want to maintian motivation for school, exercise, or pursuits of duration of any kind the key thing is to make sure the peak of dopamine if it is very high doesnt occurr too often and if something does occur often you vary how much dopamine you experience each time. - randomize dopamine so that it is intermittent before you do a task. a tool to do this is to flip a coin. - chronically spiking your dopamine to increase motivation will eventually work against you and decrease your motivation and drive - cold water can increase dopamine 2.5x above baseline but does not create a crash after. it rather tapers slowly back to baseline - working hard for sake of a reward that comes afterward can make hardwork much more challenging and make us less likely to lean into hard work.  1:39:00 - if you only get dopamine from rewards at the end of something because of the way dopamine relates to time it will make the task feel harder and longer - if you get a peak in dopamine from a reward its going to lower your baseline and the cognitive interpretation is you didnt really do the activity because you enjoyed it you did it for the reward - dont layer in sources of dopamine to start a task. instead subjectively attatch the feeling of friction and effort to an internally generated rewards system. because the mesolimbic reward system has pieces in the forebrain you can tell yourself the effort part is the good part. repeat this over and over again - in the moments of most friction you tell yourself â€œthis is very painful and because it is very painful it will invoke dopamine later, but in this moment I am doing it by choice and because I love doing itâ€ even if your lying to yourself in context of a truth which you want it to feel pleasureful. - things that can prevent getting dopamine from effort  are spiking dopamine prior to or after engagement in effort. so dont do this. - because of dopamines connection to the forebrain telling yourself something is good for you, will actually reinforce this at a chemical level - you dont want dopmaine too high or too low its all about staying in a dynamic range - dopamine establishes value not just based on the current moment but what you experience in days and years before - l-tyrosine, PEA, and Huperzine, Alpha GPC - Non perscription dopamine spikers - your previous levels of dopamine are influencing your dopamine right now and your current levels and where you take them next will influence your dopamine levels in days and weeks to come

*Top Ten Take home points:*  1. Dopamine has two pathways from which itâ€™s released. One deals with motivation and the other with movement. It can be released in small bits through neuron to neuron communication or in bulk (volumetric)  2. Doing anything that invokes a dopamine response will inevitably cause a decrease in dopamine BELOW baseline. How big that fall is has everything to do with how big the high was. The purpose of this fall is to get us to seek that behavior AGAIN which was very evolutionarily advantageous in caveman days  3. Dopamine is dynamic. How you perceive things in the present is greatly affected by your actions in the past and how you act in the present will determine how you feel in the future  4. Overtime, constant dopamine highs will deplete the readily available reserves of dopamine. If you â€œspendâ€ all your dopamine on something that â€œcostsâ€ a lot like porn, youâ€™ll only have so much left to â€œspendâ€ on other activities like studying. All dopamine is released from the same pool the same way the dollar pays for milk and napkins. Constant highs will cause a slow, but steady decrease in dopamine baseline until eventually it affects day to day life  5. Dopamine is as awesome as it is scary. Ideally, weâ€™d never spike dopamine for any reason to maintain a high baseline, but that would be a boring as fuck life. To leverage dopamine, you should do things you like on an intermittent reward schedule. The goal is to get the awesome dopamine high for pleasure and motivation on an inconsistent basis to stop baseline levels from decreasing. Basically, to keep doing the things you want to enjoy for a long time to come, you have to have some awesome days and some okay days. It may hurt your progress in the short term, but it will greatly benefit it in the long run  6. Seeking solely the reward from an activity is actually sabotaging your progress. When your brain SHOULD be learning to associate dopamine release with the difficult activity, the reward steals the thunder and the dopamine release for that whole process is skewed toward the reward. This makes doing the activity itself MORE difficult over time despite getting the reward  7. To enjoy difficult activities, you have to activate your inner Goggins and learn to LOVE exerting effort. Lean INTO the friction and tell yourself â€œI love thisâ€ even when it gets hard. Eventually, you really will start to love it and then you can take that mindset learned from one activity, like diet or exercise or studying, and apply it to EVERY aspect of your life.  8. Avoid â€œstackingâ€ multiple sources of dopamine. This will create a greater high and thus a higher barrier of entry and inevitable fall. To learn to love the activity for the effort you have to put in and NOT the reward, donâ€™t spike dopamine before or after the activity. Basically, make that shit the most interesting thing you do for that block of time  9. While dopamine has many primitive elements, itâ€™s still highly subjective. How we perceive things and whether we think things are â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbadâ€ can alter how much dopamine we get from them. This means that we arenâ€™t chained by our drives and have the power to take control of our dopamine  10. There are many substances and compounds that directly (and indirectly) alter levels of dopamine. Generally-unless for medical reasons-these should be used strategically and sparingly. Perhaps one of the most notable drugs, caffeine, actually increases dopamine receptor upregulation. It doesnâ€™t add more fuel to the car, itâ€™s more like putting it in sports mode

Per Huberman Lab protocols, I have made cold showers a frequent part of my morning routine. This morning in particular I had a breakthrough as I had the very cold water beating down on my shoulders. I asked myself: What if I SMILE while I'm experiencing this discomfort in order to signal to my body that this is an "enjoyable experience"? Will that increase my dopamine response? Though I was probably grimacing more at first, as the shower progressed my smile became more relaxed and natural. ### Summary Dopamine drives motivation, pleasure, and well-being; understanding its mechanisms helps optimize focus and satisfaction while avoiding addiction.  ### Highlights - ğŸ§  Dopamine is crucial for motivation and pleasure. - ğŸ“‰ High dopamine peaks can lead to a lower baseline afterward. - â„ Cold water exposure can significantly boost dopamine levels. - ğŸ« Certain foods and activities can raise dopamine but may lead to addiction. - ğŸ“± Excessive digital engagement can decrease overall dopamine satisfaction. - ğŸ¯ Intermittent rewards are better for maintaining motivation. - ğŸ“š Understanding dopamine can improve mental well-being and focus.  ### Key Insights - ğŸ§¬ **Dopamine's Role**: Dopamine is not just about pleasure; it regulates motivation and craving, influencing how we pursue goals and experiences. Its presence affects our drive to engage in activities.  - ğŸ“‰ **Peaks and Baselines**: After a peak in dopamine (from rewarding activities), the baseline level drops, potentially leading to feelings of dissatisfaction or lack of motivation. This cycle highlights the importance of managing dopamine levels for sustained well-being.  - â„ **Cold Water Therapy**: Exposure to cold water has been shown to increase dopamine significantly, enhancing mood and focus for extended periods. This method serves as a natural way to boost motivation without reliance on substances. - ğŸ” **Food and Dopamine**: While certain foods elevate dopamine levels, frequent indulgence can lead to decreased pleasure from those foods over time, demonstrating the risks of habitual dopamine spikes. - ğŸ“± **Digital Distraction**: Overuse of smartphones and social media can diminish our ability to derive satisfaction from real-life experiences, leading to lower baseline dopamine levels and potential feelings of emptiness. - ğŸ² **Intermittent Rewards**: Engaging in activities with unpredictable rewards can maintain higher motivation levels compared to consistent rewards, as this unpredictability keeps the brain engaged and responsive. - ğŸ‘©â€âš• **Mental Health Awareness**: Understanding the mechanisms of dopamine can aid in recognizing patterns of behavior that lead to decreased motivation or mental health issues, emphasizing the need for balance in dopamine-inducing activities.

I am 48 in August. I often hear people say it sucks getting old, but maybe I just have not experienced that. When they mention the affliction being experienced and relate it to age, I remember having similar instances when I was younger. There are also younger people that have bad backs, knees, wrists, etc., ergo I do not think that can be age alone. I know we can not take care of ourselves and/or experience extreme conditions - boxing or a car wreck for example - and have lasting affects. Placebo is also very real. Our minds are amazing, and through them we create our life scenario. We can heal ourself or begin the process of cellular decay. Things will always happen, the good the bad and the ugly, we cannot change that, though we can help influence it by our decisions haha..  What we can change is how we deal with the things that happen, perspective  and perception are key. Some people get bitter, some choose to get better. Is the glass half empty or is it half full.. or is it the perfect two fingers of whiskey *winks. Life is a grand adventure! Every adventure is full of hardships, it is inherent. Who wants to read or watch a hero that has a cake life. If you love steak and eat it every day, does the love grow or diminish - such is it for our endurance of hardships. There is so many amazing questions, so many things to learn about. I can't get enough. I have taught myself guitar, crochet, sewing (women and men in the past that had these skills were math geniuses), replaced a cv joint on my vehicle myself, discovered undocumented behavior in wolf spiders, fish for big catfish from spillways and pull them up myself with a drop net... and so much more. I think what people are missing is happiness which does not come from outside of ones self. New jobs, moving to new places, new friends, new cars and toys ... are band-aids and short lived. We have families and it is easy to give ourselves away.. to our jobs, to our children, spouses, brothers and sisters - leaving us exhausted and ready to veg to lame theatrical bs on a flickering box, or scroll through 90% crap content for 10% we might like .. .might being the operative word. Tis time to feed your soul .... nosce te ipsum. Have several hobbies that you do by yourself and occasionally with others - I fish, play with my see damn far machine (telescope), read, research, game, play guitar, sew things from my imagination ..... only boring people get bored. If you have several things to fuel your fire, then you never run out no matter how much your job or other drama in your life try to take from you. It could also be because I never grew out of the "but whyyy" stage and am excited to have knowledge at my fingertips verses only an encyclopedia ha!  Think about what you respect in others - become it, think about what you always thought about doing - do it. This short little stent we have here, we the universe getting to know ourself, is over and done all too quickly. Make the most of it while you have it - live hard, love fully, and laugh at it all because it is all smoke and mirrors. ;)

00:00:00 - 01:00:00 This podcast discusses the science behind dopamine and how it can be used to improve motivation, focus, and satisfaction. Dr. Andrew Huberman dispels common myths about the molecule and shares tips on how to leverage it for sustained energy and motivation.  01:00:00 - 02:00:00 The dopamine system is responsible for motivation, focus, and satisfaction. However, when people pursue activities that lead to huge increases in dopamine, the dopamine baseline drops afterwards, leading to addiction and depression. It is important to understand the relationship between the peaks and baseline of the dopamine system in order to make good choices that will maintain a healthy dopamine level.  02:00:00 - 02:15:00 In this podcast, Dr. Huberman discusses how dopamine affects motivation, focus, and satisfaction. He also discusses the importance of using high-quality supplements to adjust dopamine levels. Finally, he provides links to his lab's website and social media accounts.

COPIED FROM ANOTHER USER SIMPLY TO KEEP PINNED FOR MYSELF  Practical summary:   1. Dopamine management - Abstain from or limit highly desirable activities for up to a month so the dopamine levels are replenished and the baseline dopamine release returns to normal 	- Peaks of dopamine decrease our baseline dopamine, required to general motivation and satisfaction with life. - Go for intermittent, random releases of dopamine 	- Don't bundle pleasurable activities with things you want to do (gym and music) 	- Flip a coin and choose how much pleasure bundling you'll do to the next activity 	- Otherwise the activity alone becomes less pleasurable  2. Direct practices - Cold water exposure - 2.5x increase and sustained for hours afterwards - Peaks 	- Chocolate - 1.5x 	- Sex - 2x (act and pursuit of it) 	- Nicotine - 2.5x 	- Cocaine - 2.5x 	- Amphetamine - 10x 	- Exercise - 2x (up to 2x, the more you enjoy it subjectively) - Coffee combined with another activity (coffee makes the dopamine release more effective) - Connection with other people  3. Mental strategies - Subjectivity, perception and belief 	- Hearing something that validates our belief about an activity, makes it more pleasurable 	- Journaling, thinking positively about something you remember or you're experiencing now releases dopamine - Learn to spike dopamine from effort 	- Don't spike dopamine prior to engaging in effort 	- Don't spike dopamine after engaging in effort 	- Learn to spike dopamine from effort itself.

Do a social media/dopamine fast per Dr. Huberman's recommendation, then reevaluate. If you want to try getting off the addies then discuss/research a tapering plan with the prescribing physician. Your body may be "used" to Adderall but you will still experience benefits from resetting; so you don't necessarily need to stop taking it right now. Take time during this experience to think about areas in your life that may benefit from more structure. You might consider watching some videos on habits/techniques that benefit people with ADHD. It's misdiagnosed often but I would venture to say it's more likely that your doctor got it right than wrong.   That's a moot point though, as your main goal in this shouldn't be to validate a diagnosis, but rather to better your life and well-being. You will eventually gain clarity on your diagnosis, and whether it was,  or wasn't, accurate all this time, you will have developed structure and better living habits that ALL individuals need, and it sounds like you are lacking that right now. It's easier than you think though! This channel, howtoADHD, and Joshua Becker have all been very helpful YouTube channel in my journey.  I've been working on all of these things for the past few years as we realize I may have had ADHD my whole life but was never diagnosed. So now being almost 30 you can imagine the perspective and habit changes I've had to implement. But it's a very rewarding and healing process and I know you'll be glad you did.

- Dopamine is a Neuromdulator - Dopamine is resposible for Motivation, Drive, Craving, Time Perception - Dopamine has two major circuits: 1) MesoCorticoLimbic Pathway affecting motivation, drive and craving and this the part which get disrupted in addictions. 2) NigroStriatal Pathways affecting movement. - Dopamine has two ways of work: 1) Local 2) Volumetric - Dopamine is secreted in two ways: 1) Tonic. 2) Phasic. - Dopamine works by a slow process using the GPCRs. - After a peak of Dopamine, Dopamine baseline DROPS and the drop is related to the peak because of Dopamine deplation ex: postpartum depression. - Dopamine is co-released with Glutamate which is an excitatory neurotransmitter. - Dopamine stimulated the Sympathetic system. - How much Dopamine you experience from something depends on the basleline level of Dopamine then and on the previous Dopamine peaks that's why when you are repeatdly engaged in an event that is enjoyable to you, you threshold for enjoyment goes up and up. - some things affecting Dopamine: 1) Chocolate: increases baseline 1.5 2)  Sex (pursue and action): doubles the baseline 3) Nicotine: increases Dopamine 2.5 times above the baseline and it is very short-lived. 4) Cocaine: 2.5 times 5) Amphetamine: 10 times 6) Exercise: 2 times if you like it and minimal or no increase according to your love of exercising. 7) Cold Shower: 2.5 times (slowly increasing taking around 3hr to reach the baseline without crashing).  8) Caffiene: up regulates Dopamine receptors. - Addiction is progressive narrowing of the things that bring you pleasure. - A lot of ADHD are misdiagnosed because of the depletion of Dopamine that happens after engaging in actions increasing it. - Intermittent scheudle of releasing Dopamine is the key used by casinos, elusive partners and social media. - Don't allow yourself experiencing the huge peak of Dopamine unless you want to crash and wait until it becomes normal. - Remove multiple sources of Dopamine release from activities you want to enjoy. - "The Growth Mindset": learning to access the rewards from effort and doing and overtime you can evoke a Dopamine release from this friction. - Dopamine marks time, so when you put a prize after finishing a certain job, you in fact make the job more difficult and you make it harder for you to do that job again as you will need a bigger prize. - In the moments of most friction tell yourself: " This very painful and because it is painful, it will evoke an increase in Dopamine later, increasing my Dopamine baseline, and I am doing this by choice and I am doing it because I am loving it. - Do not spike Dopamine before doing an effort. - Do not spike Dopamine after doing an effort. - Learn to spike Dopamine from effort itself. - Our perception of Dopamine is hightened when the Dopamine receptors have not seen much Dopamine lately. - Viewing bright lights between 10pm : 4 am reduces Dopamine levels for several days. - Serotonin can be increased by social interactions increasing Dopamine.

This is gold.  For those electrical engineers out there, I've came up with a boost converter circuit analogy for the dopamine system.  Input Voltage (from Current Limited Voltage Source) -> Dopamine baseline  Input Capacitance -> Dopamine storage element in organism Voltage Source Current Limit (connected to input) -> determines the rate of charge (dopamine) restore  in the Input capacitance or equivalently, how quickly dopamine baseline is restored Output Voltage -> Level of Motivation / Drive / Happiness Main Transistor Duty-Cycle -> controls the spike of voltage on output (Level of Motivation / Drive / Happiness), controlled by our nervous system Inductor -> determines how sensitive will be duty cycle changes (resulting increase in Motivation)  Using the model (Examples): 1) Effect of cold exposure -> increases the voltage on input source 2) Effect of dopamine spike as a reward for something -> Depletes the stored charge (dopamine) in the input capacitor, which results in the temporary input voltage decrease (baseline drop). This happens since the voltage source is current limited (dopamine production / rate of restore is limited).

The Role of Dopamine Dopamine acts as the universal currency for exploration and pursuit, driving all mammal species, including early humans, to seek resources essential for survival and reproduction. The subjective experience of dopamine levels can significantly affect motivation:  When your dopamine level drop,you may not neccessarily feel depressed.However,  (Too)Low dopamine levels lead to a lack of motivation.  High levels result in heightened motivation.  Moderate levels can vary in effect depending on recent dopamine fluctuations.  Dopamine Mechanisms Neural Pathways of Dopamine: There are two primary dopamine pathways:  The mesocorticolimbic pathway, associated with reward and motivation.  The nigrostriatal pathway, linked to motor control.  Dopamine signals through G-protein coupled receptors, a slower method of transmission compared to the fast ionotropic transmission used by other neurotransmitters.  Dopamine Peaks and Baselines: Dopamine usually maintains a baseline level, but pursuing experiences that induce high dopamine peaks can lower this baseline over time. After peaks, dopamine levels might drop below the baseline temporarily, influencing oneâ€™s mood. Frequent peaks can disrupt this balance, underscoring the importance of optimizing the ratio between peaks and baselines for sustained satisfaction and drive.  Reward Prediction Error and Dopamine:  Reward prediction error is closely associated with dopamine, a key neurotransmitter involved in predicting and responding to rewards. This concept is crucial for understanding why certain behaviors become habitual or addictive. Reward prediction error occurs when there is a difference between expected and actual rewards, influencing dopamine release. This mechanism plays a vital role in learning and decision-making processes:  If a reward is expected and received as anticipated, dopamine reinforces the behavior, making it more likely to occur again.  If an unexpected reward is received, the increase in dopamine is even greater, which significantly reinforces the behavior.  Conversely, if an expected reward is not received, dopamine levels drop, which can demotivate the behavior in the future.    Practical Application Dopamine and Effort: Activities that increase dopamine levels can vary significantly:  Eating chocolate increases dopamine by 1.5 times but is short-lived.  Smoking and nicotine can double dopamine levels, though temporarily.  Exercise, hard work, and learning can increase dopamine uniquely, depending on the individual.  Repeated engagement in pleasurable activities can raise the pleasure threshold and lower baseline dopamine levels, akin to addiction. This understanding is crucial for effective dopamine management.  Methods to Boost Dopamine Levels Cold Water Exposure: This is a natural,harmless method to boost your dopamine level.Exposure to cold water (around 15Â°C) can significantly and sustainably increase dopamine levels, enhancing well-being and mental clarity.  Reducing High-Dopamine Activities: Temporarily abstaining or limiting highly rewarding activities can help restore normal dopamine baseline levels.  Intermittent Fasting: A healthy approach that has been practiced by different cultures,literatures for hundreds of years. This deprivation can strengthen dopamine pathways, enhancing dopamine perception. The specific intervals can vary; some may fast for 12 hours, while Huberman tends to simply skip a meal.  Reducing Light Exposure Before Bed: According to Dr. Samer Hattar's research, exposure to light from 10:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m. can reduce dopamine secretion in the following days.  Social Interaction: A 2017 study in the Journal of Science demonstrated that intimate relationshipsâ€”romantic, parental, or friendshipsâ€”can stimulate the release of oxytocin in the ventral tegmental area, an important dopamine pathway, even without physical contact  Embrace the Process, Not the Rewardï¼šIn terms of practical application, the key is to focus on engaging in activities without the explicit expectation of rewards. Frequent cold water exposure, for example, can be beneficial, especially if conducted early in the day, but the novelty and impact on dopamine release might decrease over time as you become adapted. Such activities should be approached with a mindset of embracing the process itself, allowing any unexpected rewards to naturally enhance the motivation.  This approach helps in maintaining a healthy dopamine system by encouraging activities that are rewarding in themselves without the need for external validation. Unexpected rewards, when they occur, will provide a stronger and more meaningful boost to dopamine, reinforcing the behavior in a more sustainable manner.  By focusing on the activity itself and minimizing the emphasis on rewards, we encourage a stronger, intrinsic motivation and a more resilient approach to discipline and hard work. This methodology fosters a better relationship with our activities and our dopamine system, tuning it for long-term satisfaction and success.      Conclusion Understanding dopamine's roles and mechanisms allows for better management of our behaviors and emotions, aiming for a healthier, more satisfied life. By moderating dopamine activities and focusing on natural ways to maintain dopamine levels, individuals can achieve long-term benefits in motivation, focus, and satisfaction.

I smoked cannabis for 10 years of my life. Starting at 17, every day, quite literally. I had a few unpleasant experiences while stoned, but always because I took too high of a dose, or was in the wrong setting. A few years ago I had a flare up of acute anxiety and panic attacks. Despite years of stress relief and anti-anxiety benefits from cannabis, it now seemed to amplify my  anxiety response, resulting in more frequent panic attacks. I limited my cannabis consumption and replaced most of that use with CBD cannabis, which still likely contained some THC but in low amounts. My general anxiety seemed to subside for the most part, and after awhile I started using cannabis again regularly, daily, and in increasingly stronger doses. After about a year my anxiety was at an all time high. This was mid-Covid, barely leaving the house, I was using a lot of high THC cannabis, despite having extreme anxiety. This anxious response somewhat subsided and emerged over the next few years. Fast forward to the summer of 2023 and I decided to stop using cannabis completely and I feel 90% less anxious and paranoid in general. I do struggle with these things while completely sober, but itâ€™s no mystery that cannabis has had a large effect on these symptoms. Summary of this podcast :)  The podcast is about dopamine and how it drives our motivation, focus, and satisfaction. The speaker, Andrew Huberman, is a professor of neurobiology and ophthalmology at Stanford University.  Huberman begins by dispelling common myths about dopamine, such as the idea that it is only released in response to pleasure or reward. He explains that dopamine is actually a much more complex molecule that plays a role in many different brain functions, including motivation, learning, and memory.  One of the most important things to understand about dopamine is that it is not a static level in the brain. Our dopamine levels can fluctuate throughout the day and night, and they can be influenced by a variety of factors, such as our diet, exercise, sleep, and stress levels.  Huberman also discusses the concept of dopamine schedules, which refers to the way that our brains anticipate and respond to rewards. When we expect a reward, our dopamine levels go up. But if the reward is not as big as we expected, or if it is delayed, our dopamine levels can actually go down. This can lead to feelings of disappointment and frustration.  Huberman provides a number of tips for how to manage our dopamine levels in a healthy way. These include:  * Getting regular exercise * Eating a healthy diet * Getting enough sleep * Managing stress * Avoiding drugs and alcohol * Practicing gratitude  By following these tips, we can help to keep our dopamine levels in balance and avoid the negative consequences of dopamine addiction.  I hope this summary is helpful!

TLDR: The video discusses the significant role of dopamine in motivation, satisfaction, and addiction, and explores various methods and substances that can influence dopamine levels, emphasizing the importance of balance to maintain focus and avoid overstimulation.  1. 00:00 ğŸ§  The video explores the role of dopamine in motivation, satisfaction, and addiction, its influence on mood and drive, the benefits of cold water exposure and personalized nutrition, and the impact of dopamine on neural circuits, while also discussing tools to leverage dopamine for sustained energy and motivation. 	1.1 The video discusses the role of dopamine in motivation, desire, satisfaction, and addiction, dispelling common myths, explaining its biological and psychological aspects, and providing tools to leverage dopamine for sustained energy and motivation. 	1.2 Exposure to cold water can significantly increase dopamine levels, leading to an alert yet calm state of mind, beneficial for various activities except sleep, and this effect can be sustained even after exiting the cold water. 	1.3 The podcast discusses the benefits of InsideTracker, a personalized nutrition platform that analyzes blood and DNA data for health optimization, Headspace, a meditation app that aids in maintaining a consistent meditation practice, and announces a free educational event on neuroplasticity and efficient learning methods hosted by Logitech. 	1.4 Dopamine, a neuromodulator, maintains a baseline level in the body that influences mood and motivation, and experiences of intense pleasure or desire cause temporary peaks in dopamine, which subsequently lower the baseline level, impacting our drive, excitement, and willingness to pursue things. 	1.5 Neuromodulators like dopamine, unlike neurotransmitters, influence the communication of many neurons, modulating neural circuits, affecting energy levels, mindset, motivation, drive, craving, time perception, and movement, and its depletion can lead to diseases like Parkinson's or Lewy bodies dementia, causing shaky movements, speech challenges, drops in motivation and mood, but when properly treated, can recover some movement fluidity and improve mood and motivation. 	1.6 The video explains the two main neural pathways in the brain involving dopamine, one for movement and one for motivation and craving, and how dopamine can be released locally or broadly, affecting our neural circuits and influencing our motivation and satisfaction levels.  2. 22:32 ğŸ§  Dopamine, a key molecule for movement, mood, and motivation, impacts our experiences and behaviors, can be increased by various activities and substances, and plays a crucial role in thinking and planning through the mesocorticolimbic pathway. 	2.1 Neurons communicate primarily through fast electrical synapses and slower G protein-coupled receptors, with dopamine operating through the latter, impacting movement, motivation, and even gene expression, while also co-releasing the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate. 	2.2 Dopamine, a molecule in the brain and body, stimulates alertness and desire to pursue external goals, acting as a universal currency in tracking pleasure and success, with low levels leading to lethargy and high levels to motivation, and the experience of life and motivation depends on the relative amount of dopamine compared to recent experiences. 	2.3 In the 80s, a tragic incident occurred where young opioid addicts mistakenly consumed a drug called MPTP instead of MPPP, leading to irreversible Parkinsonian symptoms due to the destruction of their dopaminergic neurons, highlighting the extreme effects of depleted dopamine levels. 	2.4 Dopamine, a crucial molecule for movement, mood, and motivation, can be leveraged through certain activities and ingestions to maintain a healthy baseline and achieve peaks, which enriches life, and it works closely with epinephrin, a driver of energy, to shape our experiences and behaviors. 	2.5 Dopamine levels, which influence motivation and happiness, can be increased by various activities and substances such as chocolate, sex, nicotine, cocaine, amphetamine, and exercise, with the amount and duration of increase varying based on the activity or substance and individual enjoyment or preference. 	2.6 The mesocorticolimbic pathway, specifically the cortical part or prefrontal cortex, plays a crucial role in thinking, planning, providing rational explanations, and assigning subjective experiences.  3. 44:39 ğŸ§  Deep engagement in activities can boost dopamine for motivation and focus, but balance is key to avoid addiction and maintain satisfaction. 	3.1 The speaker expresses a preference for Pilot V5 pens due to their writing quality and feel. 	3.2 Engaging deeply with an activity or object can increase dopamine release, but false self-reassurances or post-activity rewards can undermine this, while substances like caffeine can upregulate dopamine receptors, enhancing the effects of dopamine. 	3.3 Caffeine and other stimulants increase dopamine levels, which can enhance motivation and focus, but overuse can lead to motivation and energy issues, as dopamine, a driver for seeking and forging, is crucial for survival and reproduction, and maintaining a balance between its baseline level and peaks is essential. 	3.4 Dopamine drives the motivation to seek necessities and rewards, but after achieving these rewards, dopamine levels decrease below the initial level to stimulate further seeking behavior, a process that has existed for thousands of years across various species. 	3.5 Dopamine levels drop below baseline after achieving a goal or experiencing pleasure, which can lead to a decrease in motivation and satisfaction, but maintaining a healthy dopamine baseline can help sustain motivation and prevent addiction. 	3.6 Dopamine, a neurotransmitter responsible for pleasure and pain, can lead to addiction when activities or substances cause large increases in dopamine levels, followed by a depletion or drop in baseline levels, but understanding this relationship can help individuals make better choices to maintain or increase their dopamine baseline while still experiencing peaks of motivation and pleasure.  4

ğŸ¯ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  00:00 ğŸ§  Constructing the Iron Mindset - The importance of having an iron mindset is emphasized. - The iron mindset involves not being easily influenced by external factors. - Key takeaway: Cultivating an iron mindset is about understanding emotions, using them appropriately, and not letting them hinder progress. 02:34 ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸ Week 1: Creating Your Villain - Drawing parallels between hero stories and personal struggles. - The idea of being the hero in your own story and facing struggles as a part of the journey. - Task for the week: Create a villain, a better version of yourself, as a motivator to overcome challenges. 06:05 ğŸ“ Developing Your Villain's Qualities - Defining specific qualities for the created villain. - The importance of detailing various aspects of the villain's lifestyle and actions. - Task: Build a comprehensive list of 25-30 traits for the created villain as a benchmark for personal improvement. 13:25 ğŸš€ Lesson 2: Developing an Ego - Emphasizing the significance of having a healthy ego. - Differentiating between a detrimental ego and one that serves as a driving force. - The ego should be directed towards overcoming personal challenges and achieving goals. 15:33 ğŸ† Channeling Ego for Personal Growth - How to use the ego as a motivational tool rather than a source of entitlement. - The importance of channeling ego towards taking action and achieving desired outcomes. - Key takeaway: An ego focused on self-improvement can drive success and personal growth. 16:27 ğŸ‹ï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Facing Your Enemy: The Battle Within - You're competing against yourself, aiming to be a better version every day. - Feeling discomfort and anxiety about losing to your imagined superior self is crucial. - Victory is achieved when you surpass your personal best, representing overcoming your previous self. 20:04 ğŸ™ Gratitude and Self-Control - Gratitude is challenging when things are abundant; scarcity enhances appreciation. - Practice self-control by limiting indulgences, leading to increased productivity and genuine happiness. - Use scarcity to appreciate basic elements like food, water, and leisure, fostering an iron mindset. 25:08 ğŸš¿ Learning Through Stress: Building Gratitude Memories - Put yourself in a state of stress, then deliberately relieve it to create strong gratitude memories. - Remembering moments of relief and contentment helps cultivate a grateful mindset. - Emailing descriptions of such experiences reinforces the memory and enhances gratitude. 30:31 ğŸ Rewarding Yourself with Purpose - Pin rewards to specific objectives, ensuring they are earned rather than impulsive. - Completing goals should enhance your life positively, fostering a sense of accomplishment. - Connecting rewards to accomplishments reduces guilt and aligns with the disciplined mindset. 33:34 ğŸ‹ï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Training Your Mind for Delayed Gratification - Delayed gratification leads to better rewards. - Working hard for objectives, like completing tasks or fitness goals, makes the reward more satisfying. - Training your mind to earn things by delaying immediate desires improves happiness and discipline. 34:17 ğŸ“ Two Lists Strategy for Goal Setting - Create two lists: one for things you can afford or achieve now and another for life goals. - Set objectives for each item on the first list to practice delayed gratification. - The second list includes long-term goals that require specific missions or tasks for achievement. 36:11 ğŸš— Using Objectives as Motivation - Implement objectives to motivate actions and discipline. - Connecting desired rewards, like driving a car, to completing objectives creates a powerful incentive. - Objectives act as a barrier to undesired behaviors and drive progress towards goals. 37:22 ğŸ“‰ Tracking Failures and Accountability - Keep track of instances where you give in to impulses and fail to meet objectives. - Accountability is crucial; feeling guilty for not completing an objective enhances self-discipline. - Failure analysis helps identify patterns and areas for improvement in goal-setting. 39:01 ğŸ§  Awareness of Others' Impulsive Behaviors - Developing awareness of others' impulsive actions provides motivation. - Recognizing how easily people give in to desires emphasizes the value of discipline. - Observing others' dissatisfaction after impulsive actions reinforces the benefits of delayed gratification. 41:39 ğŸ”„ Mindset Shift: "I Have To" to "I Get To" - Changing "I have to" to "I get to" transforms the perception of obligations. - Recognizing daily activities as blessings fosters a positive mindset. - This shift in language reduces stress and increases appreciation for daily tasks. 43:58 ğŸ”„ğŸ“ˆ Empowering Yourself with "And Then I Can" - Add "and then I can" to tasks to focus on the reward or relaxation after completing them. - Associates challenging activities with subsequent enjoyable experiences. - Enhances motivation by creating a clear connection between effort and reward. The dopamine in plants is synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine, by biochemical mechanisms similar to those that animals use.

Brain dopamine receptor density correlates with social status  Date: February 7, 2010 Source: Elsevier  The researchers looked at social status and social support in normal healthy volunteers who were scanned using positron emission tomography (PET), a technology that allowed them to image dopamine type 2 receptors in the brain.  This data suggests that people who achieve greater social status are more likely to be able to experience life as rewarding and stimulating because they have more targets for dopamine to act upon within the striatum.  Dr. Martinez explains their findings: "We showed that low levels of dopamine receptors were associated with low social status and that high levels of dopamine receptors were associated with higher social status. The same type of association was seen with the volunteer's reports of social support they experience from their friends, family, or significant other."  Dr. John Krystal, Editor of Biological Psychiatry commented, "These data shed interesting light into the drive to achieve social status, a basic social process. It would make sense that people who had higher levels of D2 receptors, i.e., were more highly motivated and engaged by social situations, would be high achievers and would have higher levels of social support."

These data also may have implications for understanding the vulnerability to alcohol and substance abuse, as the work of Dr. Nora Volkow, the Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, and colleagues suggests that low levels of D2/D3 receptors may contribute to the risk for alcoholism among individuals who have family members who abuse alcohol.  The current data suggest that vulnerable individuals with low D2/D3 receptors may be vulnerable to lower social status and social supports, and these social factors have previously been suggested as contributors to the risk for alcohol and substance use.  These findings are particularly exciting because they put human neurobiology into a social context, and we humans are fundamentally social creatures. It is in these social contexts that the biological effects on behavior obtain their real meaning.

Wanted to add to the part around 1:07:00ish, where he gets into misdiagnosed ADHD - I think this probably goes without saying, but this is hugely beneficial for true ADHD folk as well. I was only recently diagnosed, but the diagnosis absolutely tracks with my life experiences. However...prior to the events that led to my depression and PTSD and the ADHD diagnosis, I was very, very functional without medication. I have two degrees and had a mostly successful career until recent events. And one of the things I've really struggled with in my otherwise quite great healthcare, is this idea that I should be on meds forever. I really don't think I should. But when I say that, my psychiatrist expressed concerns that I have a stigma against meds...when I really don't think that's the case. I don't feel negatively about medication, and it's helped me a LOT in the last year, but I've routinely felt unheard that I really was very content with my life before the events that set me off, and my personal goal is to get back to that baseline. I'm finally leaving my job this month and plan to take a break to just hike, be outdoors, touch grass, play with my dogs, detox from screens and from nonstop information and stimuli, and I really truly believe that's what I need right now. Thanks for validating my instincts. â¤

1. Cold Water therapy effects on dopamine, adrenaline and nor adrenalin 2. Dopamine can be released in 2 ways: Local release and volumetric release 3. How pleasurable or satisfying you feel doesn't depend on peak level of dopamine. It depends upon difference in baseline level and peak level of dopamine. How you feel depends upon your previous level of Dopamine as compared to present level. Many drugs just increase both baseline level and peak level instead of increasing the difference between them. A big Dopamine release makes it more challenging to achieve higher dopamine release the next time. There should not be High level nor low level of Dpamine for long.  4.Just Increasing dopamine level will make us excited but that excitement will be for very less period of time 5. Chocolate increases Dipamine 1.5 times but it goes away in few seconds. Desire of sex or act of sex increases dopamine 2 times 6. Nicotene(smoked) increases dopamine 2.5 times above base line (Very short lived) 7. Amphetamine, Cocaine, Nicotine, Sex increases dopamine in everybody that takes them. Exercise, Hard Work and Studying increasea dopamine but it is subjective 8. After achieving something, Dopamine increases but after some time it falls down. It falls down even below the baseline. The extent it drops below the baseline is directly proportional to how high the peak was. After achieving something, if you feel preety happy, the dopamine will not fall that much but if you feel extremely happy, your dopamine will fall extremely after a day or two. (Eg:- Postpartum Depression). Anyway, we return to the baseline after some time.  9. If we continue to engage in something exciting  regularly, after sometime it will be less exciting to us. 10. Some people release dopamine at higher level after a certain activity which deplete the releasable pool of dopamine. So, after sometime, dopamine falls below base level and it leads to a low feeling. Some people do the dopamine spiking activity again and again to bring back dopamine up to experience pleasure again since they are feeling low. But as we know, they have depleted the stock of releasable dopamine. The baseline begins to lower again and again. This is called ADDICTION and Addicted people don't feel pleasure at all.  11. Addiction is the progressive narrowing of things that bring you pleasure. If I am addicted to video games. I will feel happy in only playing it. I will not feel happy in exercise, study, social activity and my life will be ruined. After a some time, my system will stop releasing dopamine even after playing video games and nothing is left for me which can increase my dopamine. This is the start of depression. Spiking dopamine again and again is the main cause of decline in The baseline level. 12. If you experience a win whether it is school, sports or relationship; be highly careful about allowing yourself to experience a huge peak of Dopamine.  13. You kind of like exercise and to do exercise you increase dopamine by drinking energy drink and listen music to do exercise then you are increasing the number of conditions required to achieve the high level of dopamine by doing exercise. Don't use stimulants everytime you study or everytime you workout or anything in which you want to enjoy the process. Taking these stimulants (Music, energy drinks, Motivational reels) before the task will reduce the level of enjoyment and undermine the ability to stay motivated. The best way is to get excitement and motivation from the task itself whether it is Study or Workout. So. ENJOY THE PROCESS only. 14. Some Healthy ways to increase Dopamine so that the base level is maintained:: Cold water Therapy which increases Adrenalin and nor-adrenalin rapidly while dopamine shows gradual increase to 2.5 times above baseline and comes back to normal in 3 hours (Here there is a sustained increase instead of Rise and Crash) 15. If you work hard for the end result then the process will become very challenging. 1:39:02 is an amazing example. When someone gives reward or we reward ourself then we tend to associate our pleasure with reward rather than the work itself and if the reward is stopped, we lose interest in the process of the work. But again, Take a special care of not spiking dopamine just prior or even after to the effort. Learn to raise Dopamine from effort itself. 16. Example of Porn: Those who are indulged in it find it difficult to seek enjoyment in the productive process. Watching porn and Masturbation increase dopamine levelâ¬†ï¸ and then fall down very quicklyâ¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸ below base line . Now to raise dopamine level much higher is difficult to feel pleasure again.

This podcast discusses dopamine, its role in motivation, desire, and craving, as well as its relation to satisfaction and addiction. 01:25 ğŸŒ± Dopamine levels can be influenced by various factors, including food, drugs, caffeine, and plant-based compounds, leading to changes in baseline dopamine and how much we experience from satisfying events. 03:23 ğŸ¥¶ Exposure to cold water can lead to significant increases in dopamine, resulting in improved well-being, cognition, and clarity of mind. 05:16 ğŸ This podcast is dedicated to providing science-based information about dopamine and other related topics to the general public. 10:01 ğŸ§ª Dopamine is not just responsible for pleasure but also plays a crucial role in motivation, drive, craving, and time perception. 11:29 ğŸ§  Dopamine's effects are mediated through two main neural pathways: the mesocorticolimbic pathway (for motivation and reward) and the nigrostriatal pathway (for movement). 18:36 ğŸ§ª Dopamine can be released locally at synapses between neurons or volumetrically, influencing how our neural circuits work on both a local and broad scale. 21:00 ğŸ“ˆ Simply increasing dopamine levels through drugs or supplements may not lead to sustained motivation and pleasure; optimizing the peak-to-baseline ratio is essential for lasting satisfaction. 22:26 ğŸ§  Dopamine works through G protein-coupled receptors, taking longer to affect the brain compared to fast electrical synapses. 23:53 ğŸš€ Dopamine has two pathways for communication: one for movement and one for motivation/craving. It can also have slow and long-lasting effects, even impacting gene expression. 25:21 ğŸ’¡ Dopamine stimulates action and makes neurons more active, increasing alertness and desire to pursue external goals. 26:48 ğŸ˜´ Low dopamine results in lethargy and lack of motivation, while high dopamine leads to excitement, motivation, and drive. 29:44 ğŸ”¬ Understanding dopamine's schedules and kinetics allows for effective use of dopamine-enhancing tools for optimal motivation and drive. 35:35 ğŸ’” A tragic outbreak of symptoms caused by MPTP showed the devastating effects of severely depleted dopamine levels. 36:00 ğŸ˜¢ An anecdote about experiencing low dopamine levels due to Thorazine illustrates the profound impact of dopamine on mood and motivation. 40:29 ğŸ« Chocolate, sex, nicotine, cocaine, and amphetamine increase dopamine levels transiently, with different degrees of intensity. 44:08 ğŸ‹â€â™‚ The enjoyment of exercise plays a significant role in the dopamine increase it induces. Practicing appreciation or positive thinking about an activity can boost dopamine response. 46:30 ğŸ§  Dopamine is increased by various activities and substances, including chocolate, sex, nicotine, cocaine, and amphetamine. 46:59 â˜• Caffeine increases dopamine receptor density, enhancing the effects of dopamine. 48:28 âš  Layering multiple dopamine-increasing activities can lead to severe issues with motivation and energy later on. 49:53 ğŸ“‰ Dopamine experiences peaks and baseline levels, with excessive peaks leading to substantial baseline drops. 56:16 ğŸ’¡ Maintaining a healthy dopamine baseline while experiencing intermittent dopamine peaks is essential for sustained motivation and pleasure. 01:06:37 ğŸš« For those experiencing dopamine depletion due to excessive engagement with dopamine-evoking behaviors or substances, limiting interactions and pursuing a dopamine fast may help replenish the dopamine system. 01:09:01 ğŸ° Intermittent reward schedules, like those used in casinos and engaging activities, keep people motivated and pursuing. Dr. Huberman, thank you for existing and wanting to help humanity!  I just discovered your channel and am extremely fascinated by all this helpful content you present! You explain concepts in a very clear and interesting way, also using recent studies from prestigious medical journals to present facts and ideas in non-biased ways, allowing us to utilize this information to improve our lives.  Part of depression is not feeling any joy or motivation for anything (even for things that we once found enjoyable), because it's not engaging as it was before, and there's a lack of meaning or purpose behind it. Especially for high achieving people, always accomplishing at their highest level, and there's always that underlying question of "what's next?".  Part of it is needing extremely high levels of a certain substance/drug/activity in order to feel joy and excitement, and if we can't feel that "high" anymore, then what's the point of wasting our time and energy searching for these highs that never last and these lows that only continue to worsen.   Everyone experiences depression differently, some might feel persistent sadness and guilt, while others will feel baseline neutral to everything (even if its something considered pleasurable, like sex/alcohol/drugs/eating your favorite food, etc). Like you can literally get a high raise/promotion and still feel "meh" about it.

Practise generating feeling of extreme enthusiasm and excitement (aka release dopamine)  whenever  (1)friction arises in mind and  (2) you overcome the friction  and start the task.   Over a period of time your mind will link and relate friction with excitement making it easier for you to overcome friction and feel excited to do the tough tasks.  Second lesson is to keep overall dopamine baseline level  constant. Don't indulge too much in frivolous activities that give you a dopamine spike.  Dopamine spikes exhaust and deplete dopamine production because at a time there is only so much  dopamine your body can produce.  Hence you will not get dopamine high for other necessary activities as dopamine production capacity is exhausted and depleted in body.  You feel demotivated to do important  tasks as your body is now not able to produce more dopamine for you to get started.    Formula of success: Don't waste dopamine in mindless entertainment but keep it reserved for linking friction and stress with excitement and enthusiasm. If you can make this a habbit all stressful tasks will then start appearing exciting

I had a burned out in 2019 and I still didn't recovered completely. I Went into depression. I run a local news channel at the time, and was too excited about it. For almost 10 years I enjoyed making interviews, reports, presenting the news, but almost nobody was interested. The channel never grew up much, although I worked for 10 or 14 hours a day. One day I was completely exhausted, and I stayed exhausted for weeks. When I went a little better, I noticed that I didn't want to work on news or editing videos anymore. After that, I had no more pleasure in my life, and all things I once loved and enjoyed, I do not like anymore. I happened to stay all day on the bed, depressed, no motivated to do anything. I tried all kinds of antidepressants, and none helped. But one day I took a quarter of a pill of Ritalin 10 mg, and on half an hour, I felt that weight over me went away completely. I was normal, not elated, but not sad anymore. I noticed that there's an ideal dosage which keeps away the depression, but don't trigger hyperexcitability. Of course, I agreed with my doctor, and we developed a schedule for using Ritalin to treat depression. It's a very low dose, and not to be used every day. There are other medicines used for ADHD that improves depression, foods, exercise, caffeine, good sleep, not engaging in high peaks of dopamine. I would like to know a way to upregulate the dopamine receptors, so, my dopamine baseline would be ideal without any medicines. The good news is that I didn't get addicted to Ritalin, and get really better from my depression. I get more focus, motivation, and I began to reorganize my life. I feel the bad days are going to the past. Thanks God. ğŸ‰ğŸ‰â¤â¤â¤

Thank you Dr. Huberman for such an enlightening podcast.  I came across it today and finished in one sitting.  Here are my key takeaways for anyone interested:  Dopamine is a powerful neuromodulator, which means that it controls and coordinates different neural circuits at the same time. It is not just responsible for pleasure, but also motivation and drive. In evolutionary biology terms, it is the driver for us to seek things out that make us feel good, such as food, mates, money, and fame.   1.	Immersing oneself in cold water results in sustained release of dopamine.  2.	Baseline dopamine is the amount of dopamine circulating in the body all the time, that determines how you generally feel.  3.	The intensity or pleasure that one experiences at the height of dopamine depends upon how high that peak is relative to the baseline.  If there is a local release of dopamine along with volumetric release, the difference between the peak experienced and the baseline will be smaller.   This happens in case of volumetric release (dumping) of dopamine when you take a drug/substance.  Also, while you will feel very motivated for all things, that motivation will be very short lived.  There are thus two spatial scales for dopamine, one is volumetrically and the other synaptically.  4.	When you repeatedly engage in something that is pleasurable, such as sex, eating chocolate etc., your threshold for enjoying that thing goes up.  This is because how much you enjoy a thing depends upon the dopamine level released afterwards compared to the dopamine level before it.  5.	There are two pathways for dopamine to communicate.  One for movement and one for motivation/pleasure/desire.  6.	Dopamine and epinephrine aka adrenaline (released from adrenaline glands present on top of kidneys) are close family members and â€˜hang outâ€™ together.  There is a biochemical pathway for conversion of dopamine to adrenaline.  But adrenaline is more about the energy, whereas dopamine is about the feelings that this energy generates.  7.	There are certain activities and things that increase dopamine level, such as  -	Chocolate â€“ increase it 1.5x -	Sex or pursuit thereof  â€“ increases it 2 to 2.5x (varies for different acts involved) -	Amphetamine â€“ increases it 10x -	Nicotine â€“ increases it 2.5 times, but is very short lived.  -	Exercise â€“ can increase it to 2x times, however it depends upon subjective experience of a particular exercise.  People who do not enjoy exercise or dislike it may not experience any increase in dopamine afterwards. Same goes with hard work, studying hard, working through a challenge at the job or in a relationship.  How much dopamine is released depends upon how much you like the process itself, and not the reward of it.    8.	Layering together multiple things that lead to big increases in dopamine, can actually create severe issues with energy and motivation right after those experiences.  9.	When you experience a peak dopamine level after an activity, it will drop to baseline after sometime, and it may drop to even lower than the baseline, because of depletion of readily releasable pool of dopamine.  This is what happens in postpartum depression, when women feel depressed after a certain time of giving birth.  10.	When people get addicted to something, a time comes when they donâ€™t drive any pleasure at all from these as they stop getting dopamine release from that activity and then fall into serious depression.  11.	The key is to not expect or chase high levels of dopamine, but to go for intermittent releases of dopamine. 12.	Working hard for sake of a reward that comes afterward can make us less likely to feel motivated to do that task. There has to be an â€˜intrinsicâ€™ reinforcement rather than â€˜extrinsicâ€™ reinforcement. In case of the later, we tend to associate less pleasure with the actual activity itself than we associate with the reward.   One should learn to spike dopamine with the effort itself. 13.	The activity should itself be a reward and one should learn to enjoy the process.  Your perception of time gets altered by release of dopamine during an activity.  The time flows slowly as you are more present when doing that activity.  14.	There are activities that we can do which will help us in having this sustained release of dopamine that is beneficial for us: â€”	Cold exposure in the form of immersion in cold water.  Try to relax yourself through slow breathing if you feel uncomfortable. But if you do it too often, say everyday and become too comfortable with it, it will no longer release dopamine.  â€”	Learning to enjoy the activity, such as exercise, writing a book etc., â€”	Intermittent fasting.  We enjoy food more when we are really hungry because the dopamine receptors had not seen dopamine for some time, however a time comes when one starts enjoying the state of fasting, as there are rewarding properties in the state of deprivation too.  â€”	Nonprescription supplements like L-Tyrosine which is a precursor to dopamine.  Their effect is however short lived, and one may come crashing down once the releasable pool of dopamine depletes.  They may be taken once or twice a week, but Dr. Hubarman does not recommend their use.  â€”	Phenylethylamine (PEA) with Alpha CPG â€”	Making social connections  Thank you again for the wonderful work you are doing.

This's just a personal note of mine as someone who's trying to adress my own sense of burnout so there's gonna be a bias of focus here a bit. Also warning but swear words incoming:  Dopamine can be turnt into norepinephrine, which turns into epinephrine(adrenaline)  Dopamine works in base lines and peaks, and the state you are feeling is based on the discrepancy between the two.  A higher discrepancy leads to less reinforcement/pleasure so to say.  The mezo-cortical limbic system determines the amount of dopamine multiplier based on the subjective perception of enjoyment of said person.  Basically this enables us to be able to have a growth mindset, this lets us attach effort to enjoyment, as opposed to attaching goals to enjoyment which makes it possible for one to experience burnout.  Because burnout is the discrepancy between effort and reward.  Also due to how dopamine works, if you have a goal oriented mindset, that means dopamine is released AFTER the goal is achieved. HE AND SHE ( HEALTHY FAMILY )  It seems like you're looking for information about promotions related to supplements and a healthy lifestyle. Unfortunately, I don't have access to real-time data or current promotions. However, I can provide you with some general information about supplements and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.  Supplements are products that are taken in addition to the regular diet to provide additional nutrients that may be lacking in one's diet. They can include vitamins, minerals, herbal extracts, and other substances. Before starting any supplement regimen, it's important to consult with a healthcare professional, as individual needs vary and excessive intake of certain nutrients can have negative effects.  Maintaining a healthy lifestyle involves a combination of factors, including:  1. *Balanced Diet:* Eat a variety of nutrient-rich foods, including fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats.  2. *Regular Exercise:* Engage in regular physical activity to improve cardiovascular health, maintain a healthy weight, and enhance overall well-being.  3. *Adequate Sleep:* Get enough quality sleep to support physical and mental health. Adults typically need 7-9 hours of sleep per night.  4. *Stress Management:* Practice stress-reduction techniques such as meditation, deep breathing, or yoga to manage stress levels.  5. *Hydration:* Drink plenty of water throughout the day to stay hydrated.  6. *Avoid Harmful Habits:* Limit or avoid smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and other harmful behaviors.  7. *Regular Check-ups:* Schedule regular medical check-ups to monitor your health and catch any potential issues early.  8. *Social Connections:* Maintain a strong support network of friends and family, as social connections can positively impact mental health.  As for promotions related to supplements and healthy lifestyle products, you might want to check online health stores, pharmacies, or local health and wellness centers for any ongoing deals or offers. Keep in mind that the effectiveness and safety of supplements can vary, so it's important to research products and consult a healthcare professional before making any purchases.  Remember, the information provided here is general in nature, and it's always a good idea to consult with qualified professionals for personalized advice related to your health and wellness journey.
