Not sure if you have made a video on this before, however, it could be very interesting to learn about how external factors, such as the people you engage with on a daily basis, can affect dopamine levels. Examples of what I am talking about could be that another person you are around, quite often, has much lower levels of dopamine than you do. How does this affect your personal dopamine levels?

Personal Further Notes (In Progress): 1. The "experience" of high dopamine (high motivation, drive or satisfaction) is based on current serum levels relative to recent or baseline serum levels - from low to high feels good, from high to low does not. This effect is shown with acute and prolonged changes in perception of healthy foods, after consumption of hyperpalatable food - your brain neurochemically adjusts to make the healthy food taste less good. It's also shown with pornography use - actual sex, like healthy food, "tastes less good"; dopamine is linked hugely to sex drive. 2. Feelings of depression or a general low after a high dopamine activity is inherent to large dopamine spikes, and due to an 'overexpenditure' in synaptic release of synthesised and available dopamine. This is why spiking constantly can leave you unmotivated and feeling like shit. 3. Regardless of diversity of dopamine-stimulating activities throughout the week, repeated spiking of serum dopamine results in a lower baseline level. 4. Consistently layering dopamine stimuli eg. music + gym increases the number of conditions required to reattain this dopamine level, decreasing baseline and creating a reliance on the added layers. Anything you enjoy, wish to continue to enjoy, or wish to enjoy more, should not be layered with things like music EVERY time - it will be hard for the first week or so as you overcome your circuitry. This includes stimulants for study - save stimulants for use alongside short term things you don't want to enjoy. 5. Get yourself hooked on things you want to do more eg. gym, by intermittently varying associated dopamine spikes via layering variability and workout type variability etc. - leverage the psychology behind casino/social media addiction. This variability should not be scheduled - flip a coin to make it random. 6. When we receive a reward after an activity, you begin to enjoy the activity less - the cognitive understanding is that you didn't do it for intrinsic enjoyment; you did it for extrinsic reward. Part of this is postponing typical dopamine increases from during the activity to instead occur at its completion only. Moving through friction and hard work without reward creates wiring to enjoy the process itself. Push through effort*, and *effort in all areas of life becomes a powerful dopamine source. Tell yourself you WANT to do it every time you do it. 5. Fasting invokes greater dopamine spikes when you eat due to the deprivation. 6. Confirmation of existing beliefs spikes dopamine - browsing for relatable posts that validate your experiences or opinions can thus be addictive. 7. Social connection via oxytonin pathways evokes dopamine increase - connected to common crash after social events

I am 73-years-old and take physician-prescribed Ritalin for geriatric ADHD.  In this case, it's not a hyper-activity disorder; it's a hypo-activity disorder.  Absent the medication my brain is dead.  No amount of staring at the morning sun or exercise or taking cold showers cures it.  After watching this video, I tried to stop the medication just to see what would happen, and I sank back into dark mental nothingness.  In terms of restoring cognition, Ritalin is an absolute wonder drug. Â It gets a bad rap in my opinion.  I can confirm the cyclic nature of the treatment.  A half pill lasts 4 hours.  I rest for 2 hours and then take the other half, giving me another 4 hours.  Then I'm done for the day.  In each case, I can feel it wear off.  Otherwise, I don't feel any side effects.

Dopamine Regulation         Minimize indulgence in highly pleasurable activities for a period (around a month) to restore normal dopamine levels and reset your baseline dopamine release, essential for motivation and life satisfaction.         Opt for sporadic and unpredictable dopamine releases.             Avoid associating rewarding activities (like listening to music) with tasks you need to accomplish (like gym workouts).             Use random decision-making tools, such as flipping a coin, to decide when to combine enjoyable activities with your tasks. This can help keep the original activity pleasurable.      Specific Activities and Substances         Cold water exposure - Boosts dopamine levels by 2.5 times, and this elevated level can be maintained for hours.         Peak inducers:             Chocolate - Raises dopamine levels by 1.5 times.             Sex - Doubles dopamine levels both during the act and in its pursuit.             Nicotine - 2.5 times dopamine increase.             Cocaine - Also 2.5 times dopamine increase.             Amphetamine - Causes a whopping 10 times dopamine increase.             Exercise - Can double dopamine levels, especially if you subjectively enjoy the exercise.         Coffee, especially when combined with another activity, can make the dopamine release more efficient.         Socializing with others can also stimulate dopamine release.      Psychological Approaches         Perception and Belief:             Information that supports our beliefs about an activity can enhance its pleasure.             Positive thinking and journaling about past or present experiences can stimulate dopamine release.         Learning to Associate Dopamine Release with Effort:             Avoid stimulating dopamine release before and after performing tasks.             Try to condition yourself to derive dopamine release from the effort itself.

I have been diagnosed with Tics, which is essentially the little brother of Touretteâ€™s. I was also diagnosed with OCD and ADHD. The person who diagnosed me told me it is not uncommon for these three to be diagnosed together and also that it is extremely likely I have at least one relative with at least one of these conditions as well.  Anyway, I have learned that Tics are associated with low dopamine. So is ADHD. And OCD is often associated with unusual swings in dopamine. I personally suspect I also have undiagnosed Autism Spectrum Disorder. Back when I was diagnosed, it was believed that you couldnâ€™t have both ASD and ADHD, so they didnâ€™t even check, but it is now known not only that you can have both, but there is even a lot of overlap between the conditions. From what I am learning, ASD is associated with low folate, and folate is needed to create dopamine, so low folate can easily contribute to low dopamine. Thatâ€™s the neurochemical side. I am still experimenting with finding the right solution, but I am discovering that ensuring my diet has enough folate and magnesium is important. I started using Mucuna Puriens Extract to help with my dopamine, and it helped, but it was too much and caused a ton of intense migraines. I now have been prescribed Modafinil for my sleep problems, which is a dopamine reuptake inhibitor, and that seems to help more, but good luck finding a doctor that will prescribe it. I do worry long term that I may get used to it and it wonâ€™t work, and it still isnâ€™t an automatic cure all, but it does help.  However, specifically for Touretteâ€™s/Tics, another great thing to try is TRE (Trauma Release Exercises). Basically, sometimes why a person experiences something like Touretteâ€™s is because the body has a bunch of stored up trauma, and the Touretteâ€™s is just some of that trauma spilling over. TRE is a great natural way to let it heal it. Or if you prefer, you can also release it through cupping, massage, acupuncture, hypnosis, etc. The quality of practitioners in all of these fields varies greatly, so I recommend trying multiple people to see if they give you any relief. All of these probably partly operate on the dopamine principles presented here.  I know that isnâ€™t a perfect cure, but hopefully that gives you at least one new tool to try.

So, I watched this podcast about three times and have written a summary of 1400 words, but here I'm going to write out 8 practical (for me) thesises with no theory or explanation. Not sure it'll be useful to somebody, but it's at least a comment to support Andrew's channel:  1) Don't have huge peaks of dopamine often; they should be intermittent and random (flip a coin) 2) Don't waste your dopamine, because it's the single currency (quit palatable food) 3) Don't layer multiple sources of dopamine (music, smartphone) 4) Cold exposure 5) Enjoy the tension, don't work for a reward (a Samurai doesn't have a goal, only a path) 6) Be sure what you are doing is good for you (placebo) 7) Avoid light exposure at night 8) Social connections

What a Beautiful way of life to help us keep te balance.  I started learning more about Dopamine when I learned more about blue lotus.  Blue Lotus contains two major alkaloids within it, Aporphine and Apomorphine. Both compounds are known to have powerful effects on Dopamine receptor sites found within the limbic system of the brain. Working together, these two alkaloids have powerful modulating effects of the dopaminergic system which can often times become damaged due to prolonged use of substances and stimulants such as Opium, Alcohol, Cocaine, Nicotine, and, Amphetamines.  The Alkaloids found within Blue Lotus have been shown to stimulate dopamine production within the dopaminergic system helping to restore normal dopamine levels. At the same time, Aporphine and Apomorphine work as dopamine receptor antagonists and agonists, binding with dopamine receptors to modulate their expression and then influence neurons to increase the amount of dopamine receptor sites found at the synapse so that the body can receive and interact with its own endogenous dopamine supply. This means that the brain will now be more sensitive and aware of its internal production and release of dopamine, gently influencing the individual to seek external stimulants less and less. The alkaloid effect of Blue Lotus lasts in the body for roughly 90 minutes. These alkaloids are excreted via the urinary system leaving the brain cleansed and replenished so that the individual has reduced their desire for external stimulants. The body can now produce its own dopamine more easily, reward itself, modulate mood, behavior, and cravings for addictive substances.

Focus on the progress/activity itself. What do I like about exercise/studying/working, not the end goal!  Indulging in pleasurable activities will raise dopamine but then, it will cause a drop that goes below the baseline and it takes a while for it to go back to the normal baseline  Intermittent schedules of dopamine release:  . in order to keep baseline, when Indulging in pleasurable activities don't always search the highest pleasure. Sometimes no pleasure, sometimes a bit of pleasure and sometimes a little more (extremely high levels of dopamine will always cause the decrease in baseline that will take some time to recover)  . If activity is very pleasurable, make sure it doesn't happen often . If an activity happens often, make sure to implement intermittent schedules of dopamine  Don't reward yourself for a hard task, yet just appreciate the journey and the effort. The reward increases dopamine further, which makes the effort feel less pleasurable in comparison, and will deter you from pursuing those good activities in the future

Podcast discusses dopamine and how it affects motivation, focus, and satisfaction. The podcast dispels myths about dopamine and explores the biology and psychology of the molecule. It also discusses neural circuits and dopamine schedules, which are ways that certain substances like food, drugs, or caffeine can change dopamine levels and alter how much satisfaction people experience. The podcast provides tools for leveraging dopamine to sustain energy, drive, and motivation for long periods of time. Additionally, the podcast mentions a study that found cold-water exposure can lead to long and sustained dopamine increases, which can improve cognition and sense of well-being.

Personal notes:  Do not pleasure stack ex;  - workout + music and/or phone  - Substances + socializing or engaging in editing activities - You can use techniques like flipping a coin to decide if you mix pleasures or not. Avoid mixing automatically multiple times. This causes dopamine loss  Avoid having an automatic dopamine schedule ex;  - Gaming, substances, exiting activities, etc at the same time each day can cause lower dopamine and less enjoyment for activity  - Practice delayed gratification by refusing to reward yourself right after a task. Instant reward is counterproductive long term  - Overtime with delayed gratification your brain will release dopamine during a higher effort task. This then makes you enjoy the task more  -To better achieve this, when you find yourself in a high friction task like studying for example, tell yourself â€œI am doing this by choice and I love doing it.â€ -Do not spike dopamine prior, or after a task. Learn to receive it from the effort.   -Intermittent fasting potentially can be a great way to gradually increase dopamine, create a better headspace for hard work, and is a very healthy habit overall biologically.  -Pornography and sex reacts with dopamine the same as a savory food and really savory food. This means that regular pornography use has the potential to cause one to become less exited at the idea of sex, and favor more exiting pornography. If abused, this obviously can effect oneâ€™s love life, and sexual health.

Hey Huberman ! I have a question about dopamine levels. I've been using your tactics for attempting to improve my dopamine management and my general happiness and concentration. I have ADHD and suffer from depression (unmedicated) so my behavioural habits are very important to my daily well-being. Learning from your podcasts I have started:  - Skipping caffeine until 90minutes after waking (for me this means AFTER my morning workout now) - Workout AM (weight training: cardio 2:1) - Sauna 15 minutes 3-4 mornings a week. - Cold shower 30 seconds after sauna and heat up naturally - intermittent fast until lunch other than black coffee (usually 16:8 fasting:feeding) - High protein diet   I notice major improvements when i stick to this routine. However, last week I was sick and I found I immediately fell into some pretty low lows when I was unable to stick to my routine (particularly: no gym, no sauna, no cold shower). My question is: was this related to me having my spiking my dopamine too much with these habits? That then when I wasn't able to participate in these activities i fell into a deficiency? I was surprised how quickly I felt shitty when I lost these habits. For reference I have always been active but only been participating in this more strict routine for 1year.

I'm grateful that you chose to share this information with the public. Thank you! I've learned a lot of bits and pieces from this discussion. Unfortunately, I found it very hard to follow. With a better narrative structure, I (a software engineer) could learn more.  By contrast, your presentation on your interview with Jordan Peterson was very coherent and digestible. It had a plot line, even though it veered chaotically from one  topic to another --- and often without your control.  Maybe you could interview yourself: start with an interesting question and try to 1) give a succinct and complete answer and 2) ask an interesting follow up question on behalf of the audience, then 3) repeat.  Once you exhaust one question, "call back" to a previous discussion and ask a different question about it.  Pretend your audience is slightly smarter than you, but lack knowledge about the topic at hand. How would you communicate?  That could force you to break down the topic into smaller bites, and also give the audience a sense of progression. (I can't help wonder about dopaminergic releases here.)  Depth-first is much easier to follow than breadth first. It's like the difference between watching five episodes of TV in series vs watching 5 at the same time. Cover each topic in an order, and call back to previously discussed topics as needed.  Those were my best guesses as to how to fix it. Next, here's what I think the problem is, and if you agree it's a problem, maybe you'll have an even better solution.  As is, I found it hard to follow, and not because I don't love technical details. First, it felt like you spent 5-10 minutes giving a summary.That wastes time, since a summery isn't designed to communicate information; it only communicates intent. We have decided your intent (and ours) within 30 seconds or so of the video starting.  In fact, the entire discussion so far (first half of the video) is a survey of different ideas rather than being focused on one idea at a time. It has a very slow sense of progress towards no obvious, singular goal while jumping around between unconnected ideas.  I can't connect the dots as quickly as you change topics, and by the time you return to a topic,  we've discussed several other topics, so I don't remember anything about it and I'm unable to synthesize the facts presented into a coherent whole (to get the gist) or to follow a chain of reasoning about the few facts I managed to remember. Again, that's more tolerable in written or classroom communication.

Abstain from dopamine releasing activities for a month to bring your dopamine levels back to normal.  Instead of telling yourself that you're doing this task for a reward later (studying now for the result later), shift your mindset to the effort/task you're doing right now is the reward itself. E.g. even if you don't like studying, sit down & force urself to study and tell urself that u enjoy studying and ur putting in this effort out of choice as it is rewarding.  Eventually you will get dopamine release from studying itself and not the reward (the grade) that comes later. So the effort/process becomes rewarding rather than the end goal/result.  Dont mix dopamine releasing activities with tasks you wish to do. E.g. listening to music while working out. Listening to music spikes ur dopamine. Hence your dopamine levels get affected by it.  If u have a big dopamine release prior to a task, it makes that task more difficult as ur mind wants the same level or more dopamine release again.. e.g. u had fast food that u rlly enjoyed and now its time to study..u wont feel like studying as there wont be the drive to do so bcz of the dopamine released prior from eating (bcz studying is not as pleasurable/releases less dopamine). Hence avoid indulging in dopamine releasing activities before an important task  Take cold showers. It increases dopamine 2.5Ã— in a sustained manner meaning your dopamine levels don't come crashing down instantly after the activity is done. It is a positive way to increase dopamine with short and long term benefits.

1:37:55 forward - this is my problem. I am constantly celebrating, pretending like I am at my end goal even tho I am far from it. I have fantasies about being intreviewed about the hard work I did to become successful BUT I HAVEN'T DONE IT.  I make small progress and then celebrate the hell out of it for weeks instead of going further. I am 100% focused on the goal/reward/celebration and not on the process/work.  I give myself a boost through energy drinks to get even more dopamine, and constantly eat chocolate and stuff at the end of the day to give myself a reward. I get very little from just working which is why I just can't bring myself to do it.
This should be taught to all addicts, i wish i had known this earlier. God bless you andrew

Also side note, increased awareness of symptoms may help increase the diagnosis of narcolepsy. I know it took me a long time, 10 + years to have a formal diagnosis. I just thought, Iâ€™m not special, everyone is tired, suck it up, throughout undergrad. Then in nursing school before my cataplexy kicked in, I again thought, Iâ€™m just as tired as everyone elseâ€¦ working night shift in the ER, same thing. Then finally once I got on day shift decided to have a sleep study and was diagnosed.

it's incredible how quick that celebration mechanism kicks in in my brain. after writing the comment above I instantly imagined myself being interviewed and saying "and that was the day I realized what was wrong and I became super successful" NO! THE WORK IS NOT DONE! WHAT THE HELL! STOP CELEBRATING. THERE IS NOTHING TO CELEBRATE.

what I'm doing from here on out, now, in the moment:  - realize that I am focusing on the end reward / celebration and not the work, and it is making me not want to do things even though I know they are very beneficial for me to do. - start telling myself that the effort part is the good part. - stop using external rewards / dopamine amplifiers such as energy drinks, music, (alcohol & weed in some instances), junky food at the end of the day. - do work with zero external pleasure or distraction.     - I will not be able to do a lot of work, might get bored after 2 minutes, but I will at least try. Just push though it. Keep repeating to myself that the effort part is the good part.

quick story: when I was in school I could just focus on the reward because it wasn't so much effort to get a good grade. so I'd focus on the grade and work a bit and get it, happy times. then in finals in high school there was so much material to go through that it didn't work. so I started drinking energy drinks every day, smoking weed all the time, even drinking alcohol as I was studying, just to get the dopamine up so I could keep going. it worked, I got decent grades after ~4 months of this. then I crashed for like a year after doing that, full on depression.  I need to understand that hard things require a lot of effort, effort I may not be used to putting in. so focus on the work, focus on the process. the effort part is the good part.

Baseline Dopamine circulates through body. Strong cravings and desires causing dopamine peaks decrease this baseline afterwards.  Tonic Phases: Baseline Level Phasic Phases: Peaks  Dopamine is a Neuromodulator ( Neurotransmitters are involved in dialogues between neurons, whereas Neuromodulators are involved in influencing the coordination of many neural circuits ). So dopamine is directly responsible for activity and inactivity of a bunch of neural circuits.   Dopamine is directly responsible for Pleasure, Motivation, Drive, Craving and Time Perception. Dopamine is important for movement. For context, people with Parkinson's have some part of their brains with depletion and death of dopamine neurons. Being recovered, they regain fluidity in movement and general happiness
Mesocorticolimbic Pathway: Reward, Reinforcement and Motivation Nigrostriatal Pathway: Movement

Andrew Huberman  ______________________ Controlling your dopamine for motivation, focus & satisfaction.   What is dopamine   Thereâ€™s no such thing as dopamine hits. Thereâ€™s a baseline of dopamine. Meaning amount of dopamine circulating in your brain and body.  Dopamine is important for how you feel. Good mood, motivation, drive, excitement, pleasure, focus etc.  When you experience or crave something very pleasurable, desirable, excitable, your dopamine peaks, and when you stop doing that, your dopamine drops below baseline and youâ€™re in bad mood  Dopamine drops below baseline symmetrically to how much it peaked because there is not a lot of dopamine around, since it was used when it peaked  These peaks influence how much dopamine will be circulating afterwards.  In neuroscience literature there are two types of dopamine release, tonic and phasic. Tonic: the low level baseline thatâ€™s always there being released and circulating  Phasic: peaks that ride above the baseline  Youâ€™ll feel extreme, unimaginable sadness if you get dopamine receptors removed or blocked. like Andrew once got them blocked when he got thorazine shot.   Why dopamine is important   Our level of dopamine is the primary determinant of how motivated and excited we are, also our drive, craving and time perception.  Dopamine is important for movement.  Dopamine is important for moving us towards our goals and how much we remember enjoying our past experiences. Itâ€™s primarily determinant of our quality of life and happiness.  Dopamine is super important molecule in our body. It makes life worth living   Facts about dopamine   Dopamine has close friends in nervous system. Epinephrine (adrenaline) is the main driver of energy. We canâ€™t do ANYTHING without it.   Adrenaline is made from dopamine.  Chocolate increases dopamine baseline level 1.5 times. Pursuit and act of s*x - 2x Nicotine - 2.5x Cocaine - 2.5x Amphetamine - 10x ^the are very short lived, these dopamine peaks last for few minutes or seconds. Then your dopamine level will drop below baseline and youâ€™ll feel sad. If you like exercise, it will increase dopamine by 2x. If you donâ€™t, itâ€™ll little bit or not at all  If you like doing something, even talking about pen you love, itâ€™ll increase your dopamine.  Lying to yourself about you loving doing something wonâ€™t work.   Why do we have dopamine?   Dopamine is universal currency of forging and seeking. Meaning seeking things that will provide sustenance and pleasure in the short term (food, water) and will extend our species in the long term   Once our ancestors hunted animal, theyâ€™d get dopamine peak. However after it dropped, theyâ€™d go out and hunt again. This is the way our nature is set up for human survival.  Having high level of dopamine baseline is what drove evolution of our species    Donâ€™ts about dopamine   Donâ€™t combine pleasurable things with unenjoyable activities. e.g. Gym + music or coffee. That way you are making it harder to enjoy gym  Be careful to how much and how often you get peaked dopamine so that you donâ€™t get addicted.  Donâ€™t use stimulants for doing activities (for example motivational videos/energy drink for studying or workout) each time you do, you will need more and more of that stimulant to do that activity in the future.  Caffeine can boost dopamine. We donâ€™t have enough studies, but it can be dangerous as well.  Avoid all sorts of drugs, stay natural   How to increase dopamine   The real key to increasing dopamine baseline without dropping afterwards is not chasing or expecting it  If you want to maintain motivation for school, exercise, relationship, the key is not experience dopamine peaks regularly (quit those bad activities)  Understand that your ability to experience motivation and pleasure for what comes next is dictated by how much motivation and pleasure and dopamine you experienced prior  Dopamine controls our time perception. If you do something for sake of reward, your brain wonâ€™t release dopamine during the process.  Adapt a growth mindset: your goal must be not results/reward, but the process, effort, striving itself. Tell yourself, this effort is great, pleasureful, even if itâ€™s painful.  Never tell yourself â€œIâ€™m gonna push myself todayâ€ because your brain will focus on end goal.  The longer you deprive yourself from something, the better it feels (more dopamine will be released)    Increasing dopamine with intermittent fasting   One of the great ways to increase dopamine is by intermittent fasting.    One of the reasons it works is because we are aware and keep reminding ourselves that â€œoh Iâ€™ve been fasting for 12 hours Iâ€™ll have high dopamineâ€  Telling yourself that certain behavior is good for you will increase dopamine.  Study showed that hearing something that reinforces oneâ€™s prior behavior, can evoke dopamine and the word for release.   Being exposed to cold to increase dopamine   One of the super effective ways to increase dopamine baseline is taking cold showers, popularized by Wim Hof.  Research: 3 humans were exposed to warm, moderate and cold water. Person who took cold water increased his adrenaline, and dopamine by 250% above baseline and it was sustained for 3 hours. People use this â€œcold water therapyâ€ for Metabolism, fat loss, well being, To improve cognition, and clarity of mind  Donâ€™t force it to not to get hypothermia. Itâ€™s also better to take it in the morning or afternoon, not before sleep.  When getting exposed to cold water, once it gets comfortable, you no longer release dopamine.

For my own reference- 10:15 Tonic & Phasic dopamine. Tonic = baseline dopamine that's always circulating in your brain. Phasic = peaks of dopamine from reward. 12:09 Difference b/w someone with endless drive & someone who has given up and has no drive = Tonic dopamine. 12:42 Dopamine is a Neuro-modulator not a Neuro-transmitter. Neuro-modulators affect the system as a whole Vs. Neuro-transmitters affect local neurons. 13:18 Dopamine controls the probability that certain neural-circuits will be active and other circuits will be inactive. 13:30 Controls our levels of Energy, mindset, drive, craving, mood & motivation, Time-perception. 13:59 Time perception. Importance of accessing/controlling dopamine at different time-scales to sustain your drive/effort. 14:29 Dopamine & movement. Parkinsons - depletion/death of dopamine neurons in certain areas of brain that causes shaky movement, challenges in initiating movement & speech, depression. 17:45 Two main circuits/pathways for dopamine in brain - Movement and (Reward, reinforcement, motivation). 20:23 Drugs & supplements that increase dopamine will make it harder for you to sustain dopamine release over the long term. 18:14 Local Vs. Broad release of dopamine. (Synaptic Vs. Volumetric release. Tonic Vs. Phasic.) 20:52 Level of satisfaction from a behavior depends upon the "difference" of baseline and peak. It depends on the height of the peak relative to the baseline. 24:33 Two pathways- Movement Vs. (Reward, reinforcement, motivation). Two spatial scales of release in brain - Synaptic Vs. Volumetric. Temporal scales of release - Slow Vs. Very long-term effects to the point at which it can even control gene expression. 25:07 Dopamine is excitatory because of Glutamate. It's addictive. Tells the brain, "this feels good, I want more". Whereas inhibitory neuro-transmitters (Serotonin) aren't addictive. They tell the brain, "this feels good, I've had enough." 25:37 Dopamine stimulates action because  37:35 Dopamine is the parent of Adrenaline.  39:17 Dopamine is about pleasure. Adrenaline is about energy. Adrenaline alone causes anxiety, fear etc. Add dopamine to the mix and you get pleasureful attentiveness. 41:32 Chocolate - 1.5x dopamine increase above baseline. It's like a lowering sine wave after each cycle. The baseline keeps getting lower & lower. Ultimately leads to severe depression. 1:03:21 Burnout = progressive lowering of dopamine baseline through repeatedly engaging in stimulating activities without letting the system reset. Once a certain threshold is crossed, you slip into depression. 1:05:45 How to let the system reset = dopamine fast. Iâ€™m interested to learn more about the coffee effect. If I heard correctly, Dr. H said that it doesnâ€™t increase dopamine directly, but it does increase dopamine receptors. I have heard of other situations where that can be a bad thing. For instance, pitocin, the synthetic version of oxytocin, also has the effect of creating more oxytocin receptors in the uterus. This actually makes it harder for a woman to go into labor naturally after previously having an induction, because her body will not produce enough of her own oxytocin to fill all those extra receptors and trip the cascade of hormones necessary for labor. I wonder if having more domapine receptors requires us to pursue higher dopamine activities in order to fill the extra receptors and feel the effect, leading to lower mood on a regular basis if one is not a natural thrill seeker. I know that when I gave up coffee my baseline dopamine improved drastically, after a few months.

----- Summary ------  Dopamine introduction: â‡’ Dopamine is a chemical/molecule in the body released by certain neurons. It is the molecule responsible for movement, mood         and motivation. Having more of it makes you feel better/more pleasurable. It is a universal currency, different activities use the       same dopamine system for reward. â‡’ Dopamine is also linked to energy as it is a close relative of adrenaline, peaks in dopamine also leads to peaks in adrenaline       since adrenaline can be manufactured from dopamine. The release of adrenaline release wakes up neural circuits of the brain       and body and give us readiness. Adrenaline alone can be fear/mental paralysis/trauma, but dopamine colours the experience       and when paired with adrenaline, becomes excitement. â‡’ Dopamine stimulates action in general because the neurons that release dopamine co-release glutamate, which is an excitatory       neurotransmitter that makes neurons electrically active. This increases the level of alertness/readiness and desire to pursue       things outside the confines of the body. â‡’ Dopamine has 2 pathways to communicate - 1 for movement, the other for motivation and craving. â‡’ Dopamine can be released globally (volumetric release - increase dopamine baseline) or locally (synaptic release - result in       dopamine peaks) from vesicles that contain dopamine.  What are dopamine peaks and baseline? â‡’ Baseline - The dopamine baseline is the amount of dopamine released and circulating in your entire body all the time/by default.       It is like the steady/prolonged level of dopamine in the body.       â†’ A small drop in baseline dopamine levels may not be noticeable, but when it falls below a certain threshold, a drop in            motivation or drive can be felt.      â†’ Everyone has a certain baseline level of dopamine, some of this is genetic. People with higher dopamine baselines are more             excited and motivated in general, while people with lower dopamine baselines are more lethargic in general. â‡’ Peaks - Dopamine peaks are the temporal increases in dopamine levels when you do something you enjoy. Peaks in dopamine       usually fall back to slightly lower than baseline and decrease baseline dopamine after the peak. The bigger the peak the greater       the fall. This causes you to feel down after experiencing something very enjoyable.      â†’ How enjoyable something feels is related to how high the dopamine peak is above the baseline and also how high the peak is            compared to recent peaks.      â†’ When dopamine peaks are too high/frequent, it depletes the readily releasable pool of dopamine (vesicles do not have            dopamine to release) and causes the dopamine baseline to be lowered.  Practical Uses: â‡’ Increase dopamine released from a particular activity/prevent decrease of dopamine released from a particular activity:       1. Practice journaling or appreciation of the activity. Encouraging oneself to think positively about an activity has a profound            impact on its rewarding properties. Knowledge of the benefits of what you are doing and focusing on it also helps with            releasing dopamine from the activity. Vice-versa.            (This is possible because of the mesolymbic pathway of dopamine that involves the pre-frontal cortex)           For example, try to attach the feeling of friction and effort to an internally generated reward system. Tell yourself the effort part            is the good part. Tell yourself this is very painful, and because it's painful, it will increase dopamine later, but in that moment,            you are doing it by choice and because you love it.      2. Take caffeine prior to performing the activity. Caffeine alone (an exception to dopamine layering) upregulates dopamine            receptors and allows you to experience the effects of dopamine more.            Coffee/Tea/Yerba Mate is recommended, Yerba Mate has the additional benefit of protecting dopaminergic neurons.      3. Avoid layering activities that release dopamine. This increases the number of conditions required for the activity to be            pleasurable and causes the activity to feel less pleasurable alone. For example, stop using the phone to browse social media            during other activities like working out.      4. Do not spike dopamine prior to, or after the activity by trying to incentivize the activity using a reward, try to get dopamine            released from the activity itself instead. When given a reward, less pleasure will be associated with the activity itself. Without            the reward, over time, dopamine can be released during the activity itself just by forcibly engaging in it. Dopamine released            during the activity will also make the activity itself more efficient due to how dopamine affects time perception and energy. â‡’ Maintain healthy levels of baseline dopamine:      5. Avoid having too large/too frequent dopamine peaks to avoid depleting the readily releasable pool of dopamine and causing            dopamine baseline to fall. Intermittent release of dopamine is key. Ensure large dopamine peaks do not occur too frequently            or frequent dopamine peaks are not too large.      6. Engage in cold water therapy, this increases baseline by up to 2.5x for a few hours before it reduces back to baseline.      7. To recover to dopamine baseline setpoint, avoid dopaminergic activities. The dopamine system will replenish itself naturally.

By some remarkable coincidence, the value of an intermittent reward schedule is the very subject of one of Shakespeareâ€™s sonnets, No. 52.  So am I as the rich, whose blessed key Can bring him to his sweet up-locked treasure, The which he will not every hour survey, For blunting the fine point of seldom pleasure.  Therefore are feasts so solemn and so rare, Since, seldom coming, in the long year set, Like stones of worth they thinly placed are, Or captain jewels in the carcanet.  So is the time that keeps you as my chest, Or as the wardrobe which the robe doth hide, To make some special instant special blest, By new unfolding his imprisonâ€™d pride.  Â Â Â Â Blessed are you, whose worthiness gives scope, Â Â Â Â Being had, to triumph, being lackâ€™d, to hope.  Here is one interpretation of this famous Sonnet 52:  Iâ€™m like a rich man with a key to his locked-up treasure, who refrains from opening it up and looking at his riches all the time â€“ itâ€™s better to open the treasure chest only rarely, because then the pleasure of gazing upon his riches is heightened. [The fine lines 3 & 4 are key, at the core of the "Intermittent Reward Schedule" concept.] Or itâ€™s like feast days which are rare and scattered throughout the annual calendar, like rare gems, or precious jewels set in a necklace (or carcanet).  [Then the poet switches to the highs resulting from his occasional meetings with the young man he loves.] The time when we are apart is like that treasure chest, or like a wardrobe which houses a fine robe; knowing itâ€™s there but being unable to touch it all the time makes those special times when you can touch it even more special. [Lines 11 & 12 repeat the principle of Controlling the Peaks of Pleasure by limiting them to irregular or special times.] You are truly blessed [Fair Youth], because when someone possesses you they feel they have triumphed, and when someone lacks your presence, they live in hope and anticipation of being with you again. It doesnt make sense to me why increasing the supply of something that may or may not be converted into dopamine can be bad, but I think I have some ideas. One is the body may naturally regulate a homeostasis and so if your body has more tyrosine than it needs and cant get rid of it it may produce spikes in dopamine accidentally through overly large supply and then it may also tell the body not to produce as much in the future;. I think this is called dopamine down regulation but it may have something to do with the receptors being filled and saying "no more" and there being no more room for additional dopamine until the receptors are cleared. If they are filled all at the same time perhaps this could cause issues.  It seems to me there has to be a way to engineer both higher levels of motivations without crashes or a managble cyclicality of both sides of supply of dopamine through tyrosine and the potency of dopamine through cycling on and off of both supply (tyrosine) and demand (dopamine release asking for more dopamine). It's a bit more complicated as receptors are also involved and need time to clear (metabolism determines how fast) and there are other variables. But cycling between Tyrosine and Tyrosine fast (during that period consuming Tryptophan and seratonin) and from cycling on and off dopamine releases with the right timing and in the right order seems to be something worth experimenting with.  Tyrosine and Tryptophan I believe compete for the same resources to synthesize into either Seratonin or Dopamine or else they compete for the same receptors so there is some opposite mechanism and healthy balance between the two that has to be maintained. Dopamine is the drive, Seratonin is the comfort. You don't want to be too comfortable all of the time but you don't want to be too driven without enjoying the process and too dependent upon the ups and downs of the addictive nature of dopamine. Too much seratonin can make you comfortable, content and happy when you maybe shouldn't be, which makes life good but may prevent you from having the necessary drive to create something better. But any goal seeking or system requires you to occasionally enjoy the journey otherwise what is the point.

1. After the dopamine spike, it tends to drop below the baseline. 2. Dopamine can be produced locally and globally. 3. 2 paths for dopamine 4. Synapse is space between neurons and neurons send signals to synapse to activate neurons 5. Appreciating the process of something can increase the level of dopamine when you are doing that action (I love programming, I love building stuff) 6. Dopamine is currency for seeking and foraging 7. Higher the spike, greater drop of dopamine 8. Why do we have a huge drop in dopamine? Because our dopamine in the pool runs out 9. Intermittent schedule (you can't predict) 10. Don't combine things to get dopamine (e.g. listening to music during workout), and only get dopamine from the thing you are pursuing. Reduce multiple sources of dopamine release on things you enjoy (no smartphone during work out for me now) 11. Caffeine can increase the performance of dopamine receptors, so it can be helpful if you intake them correctly 12. Release dopamine during the effort, not before or afterward. Remind yourself that you made a choice and you love putting effort.

All your videos are Wonderful, made to perfection & packed with Vital information...but this one..so far..is my Fave.  ..i was a weird kid..some said i was never a kid & it certainly feels that way. Don't know how or when i began reading but i was reading adult books by age 3..so..grade school was a Huge incredibly long snooze..that said, my Fave professions are Science & Medicine..& Technology, in that order. Settled for a degree in Computer Science because my father had his first Big heart attack the summer before i was to go to Columbia to become a Doctor, specializing in DNA research. In the blink of an eye Family Responsibility kept me from realizing that dream. If i had not stepped up he would have had more due to the stress alone & i could not ignore that fact. Bottom line, i have always had an innate comprehension of how the body & the mind work, as if i could see inside the body & locate the trouble instinctively..often the root cause was bad diet, or, over indulgence, personal physical abuse, & toxic environments..Then i would recommend changes corresponding..& with Accuracy. Many lives were & still are saved by simple changes & others were remarkably prolonged despite adverse conditions & situations.  One thing i have been saying all my life, Do Not ignore the mind..Treat the mind With the body...rings True today more than ever, since mainstream medicine has disconnected from common sense & simply relies on Big Pharma for panacea, the 'Holy Grail miracle pill'. i studied the area/s anyway, in my free time, so..i understand a thing or two about the science, just minus the Degree. So much so, that fellow scientists choose to consult with me, while knowing i lack the paper. Since i did not get to the Med classes..i know there will be things, loose strings & not easily discovered answers, that you will clear up & explain in this video. Halfway through your video now & i have heard a TON of Common Sense explaining tricky little dupes we do to ourselves..my instincts have been serving me well..lol..i have made Huge Effort to not get too high on Happy, so as not to crash & burn later on.. i wonder..can't help it. my thoughts keep coming back to the Locked In syndrome....could these patients not be taught to create New neural pathways?..or..does it affect the whole brain as one...i'm guessing this must be the case. & i am Grateful you were conscious enough to Stop that Thorazine! & tell them what you Needed...worse than LiS, it would have killed you. Reminds me of when my ulcer perforated, one night at the end of a particularly difficult work shift..i drove to the hospital with blood trickling out of the corners of my mouth..within seconds the ER Dr on call was literally running around shaking her hands, freaking out..she had no idea what to do..so i asked for vitamin K shots...like your call, it did the trick. i'm still here too.  Stepping out soon as the video is done for my daily small chunk of dark chocolate..keeping it small so as to prevent too much "vomiting out into receptors" .....i may put this Priceless little Gem on a T shirt, giving You the credit of course..*laughs*  We Desperately Need Humor to Survive, especially in these dark days. Dopamine down regulation in reference to a short bout of phasic firing from one instance is so miniscule that your average person cannot notice it. And things that are encoded in our genetics for every day life/survival such as eating(proper foods), cleaning, etc, the tiniest down regulation that occurs rebounds within hours. It's not until you abuse the action potential by repeating things too often that the down regulation repeats before the brain has the ability to get back to a homeostatic baseline. Even then, things the body is designed for don't create complete tolerance, otherwise orgasms would lead to absolutely no feeling when abused. The dopamine system is fairly robust when it comes to down/up regulation compared to the other NT systems. This is in part why it takes quite a while to build full tolerance to things like adderall, or other drugs, or sugar/junk food binging, tv show binging, etc.

Dopamine is both a neurotransmitter and neuromodulator. Though in reference everyone knows the 3/4 main modulators as neurotransmitters and is what they always think of them as. It's a little Offsetting to not actually tell people this because it makes for a confusing correlation

The â€œbaselineâ€ is the key. Focus on doing things that are proven to raise your baseline. Set you mind on the discipline it takes to do the discipline itself. For example.. The reward of eating broccoli isnâ€™t that you trick yourself into enjoying broccoli.. but that you know eating broccoli is difficult and not enjoyable but you are rewarded by the discipline youâ€™re practicing by eating the broccoli.  This works for every single aspect of life. The discipline of setting your alarm.. The discipline of not tap the snooze button but immediately getting up. The discipline of then doing every single thing after that regardless of if itâ€™s enjoyable and specially if itâ€™s difficult! Making your bed.. Reading scripture.. Praying.. Exercise.. Nutrition.. Work.. Relationship.. Rest.. Therapy.. Serving Community.. Sleep. All these become disciplines instead of â€œchoices based on pleasureâ€. Then your baseline will be higher which only helps you be even more disciplined. HOWEVER.. Life has a way of throwing us off balance and setting us back. So also be fully prepared to be disciplined through â€œtrials and temptationsâ€.. Like very real troubles that may force you to drastically adjust you daily routine of disciplines. Like an injury or emergency surgery or the loss of a loved one.. or even something simple like a flat tire. These very real stresses come with temptations to â€œseek pleasureâ€ and cause us to fall back into practicing pleasures that spiral us down. So stay focused on the disciplines through the trials and traumas and youâ€™ll keep your baseline of dopamine and the other pleasure hormones high and the stress response hormones stay low!

I was diagnosed with ADHD at 38, I could feel Adderall work about 15 minutes into it.  10mg put me to sleep, 20 put me to sleep, 30 had almost a narcoleptic effect.  40mg extended release twice a day seemed perfect.  However I hate taking meds and in my view for most things they should be more like a bandage than a permanent fixture.  So at nearly 42 I am at 30mg once a day.  My thinking, which subjectively seems to be accurate with my body is by giving my body what levels of dopamine I needed and then slowly reducing this amount I allowed my brain to realize I needed a higher level and to start producing it on its own.  So far so good.  I hope to be off of Adderall completely in 24 months and this information I feel will help me achieve this goal faster.    I also skip days.  However when I was sick once I didnâ€™t take the Adderall for about 3 days, by then I was crying, only able to stop for 3 minutes at a time and I was suicidal.  30 minutes after taking a dosage I was no longer crying or suicidal.  So I decided then to move slowly with getting off the medication.    Now knowing methamphetamines are neuro toxic I want off Dextroamphetamine more quickly!  Thanks for this information!

A summary of this podcast:  1)What actually is dopamine?  It's the driver to seek things. It is the only currency to seek motivation, desire and cravings. It has everything to do with our mindset and how we approach things.  2)How dopamine works in our body?  So there's a common myth associated with it called as the dopamine hit which is not completely true. Dopamine has a baseline level and a peak level and the balance between these two levels determines the  satisfaction and motivation we get.  3)Satisfaction  The relative height of the peak level with respect to the baseline level is directly proportional to the satisfaction we get after achieving something or doing something. The past dopamine level affects our present dopamine.  4)Motivation   It is the internal energy to seek things. How motivated we are depends on our present dopamine level relative to our past dopamine level. Motivation should arrive from the process itself not the end goal or reward.  5)Affects of supplements  Supplements taken for dopamine of any kind do help us to reach the peak for sometime but if taken too often then it lowers and lowers our baseline level which is unhealthy for us in the longer run and that is why we start feeling unsatisfied  6)Subjective nature of dopamine  Dopamine is highly subjective. Many people find difficulties in enjoying the process as it's ofc not so pleasurable but if we stick to it even if we don't want to time and again, then dopamine starts getting generated from this process itself  7) Instant pleasures Instant pleasures of any kind are not even useful in the shorter run forget about the longer run as when we seek those pleasures then the peak level is achieved and then it abruptly drops below the baseline level after which we even loose the basic motivation  8) Addiction  When the baseline dopamine level keeps getting lower and lower and when it drops below a minimum healthy level then, this condition is referred to as addiction. And this is when the real problem starts as now the person doesn't feel the pleasure or joy anymore.  9) What's the solution   â˜…If you seek too high dopamine from something, then don't seek it too often â˜…In order to get dopamine from something don't use any stimulants as they kind of wear and tear your mind for seeking dopamine form that activity again without any stimulants.  10)Some helpful practices   ğŸ”¹Cold water exposure: highly recommend as it provides long lasting and stable dopamine level balance  ğŸ”¹ Better sleep ğŸ”¹ Spiking dopamine from effort itself ğŸ”¹Any subjective activity that you like. And a lot more that can't be described in comments.

I live in central Chile, and the temperature of the Pacific Ocean in Valparaiso can range between 63.9 F mid summer to 55 degrees F in winter.  When I was a child I would go to school, come home for lunch, my dad would pick me up from the bus and take me swimming in the olympic sized pool next to the ocean to practice swimming, then I would eat lunch and go back to school.  Lunch was 2 hours long.  I recall being very comfortable in that water temperature, though it was always a shock getting into the pool.  With my cousins over the weekends we would play in the pool for an hour.  I loved it.  My dad was an athelete, and he swam in the Ocean every day until he got ALS in his 80s. It's a matter of geting used to it and feeling safe about getting into the cold.  Now I have additional insight into why that was the best part of my childhood.

*What did i learn from this podcast:*  - cold showers are essential to my day, it can increase dopamine by 2.5 times (equivalent to that of cocaine ) but instead of having it crash down it maintains after! - Dopamine is a finite but renewable source, this means that if you were to have a big spike in dopamine it comes crashing down but it would go below your baseline, this will make you feel worse - If there are activities you want to continue doing, avoid stacking dopamine spiking activities together like pre workout, music, texting and working out if you wanna continue working out, the same principle will apply to studying etcâ€¦ - if there is an activity you find difficult like studying, donâ€™t spike dopamine before and after the activity, instead make yourself derive dopamine from the activity (studying itself). Especially when there is a great resistance to the activity, tell yourself that despite the activity being hard and difficult you are doing it BECAUSE you enjoy it! - â€œDonâ€™t spike dopamine prior to engaging in effort, and donâ€™t spike dopamine after engaging in effort. Learn to spike dopamine from effort itself.â€ - Andrew Huberman  1:47:31 - Working only for the sake of a reward that will come afterwards can make it more challenging and us less likely to do it in the future because of the way dopamine affects time perception and only being released at the reward. This relates to growth mindset, pleasure from the process, from conquering the effort (deliberate effort exposure).

Your Past Level of Dopamine affects your Current Level and this will again influence your Future Levels. . . . B. Long Version  I. Dopamine System can be Controlled up to significant levels.                                       1. By our Conscious -> Awareness -> Control                                                                 1.1. We all have a baseline of dopamine in our bodies                                                                 1.2. We need to avoid spiking it too High as there are                                                                          eventually Crashes which follow the Extreme                                                                          Highs in Proportion. (like a Sugar Rush)                                                                 1.3. Why is this the case? Dopamine is limited and                                                                          takes time to replenish.                                                                          - Both in Short Term & Long Term.                                                                 1.4. Key here is like most things in life, Moderation or                                                                         Balance.                                                                          - Applicable to daily activities.                                       2. Which incorporates using tools/techniques/methods like:                                                                 2.1. Limiting Highly Stimulating Activities up to 1 or  2                                                                         times a week.                                                                                       (i) includes any kind of activity like Food,                                                                                             Alcohol, Video Games,                                                                                            Social Interactions.                                                                                       (ii) key here once again is like most other                                                                                             things in life, Moderation or Balance.                                                                2.2. Enjoying the Process itself                                                                                       (i) through words of affirmation                                                                                      (ii) not "Layering" additional external                                                                                          sources of                                                                                                            dopamine as a reward, both prior and                                                                                         after the activity.                                                                                      (iii) I.e. the key is to do the activity                                                                                           that you want to pursue                                                                                          or enjoy with sole focus                                                                                          on it or in a naked way.                                                                                      (iv) I.e. without any additional pleasure                                                                                         inducing elements, for example,                                                                                         Studying or Working out with Music                                                                                         or taking Caffeine                                                                                         or Pre Workout Stimulants.                                                                   2.3. Creating a System of Habits or Lifestyle                                                                                       (i) Minimal type lifestyle                                                                                         - for highest efficiency  II. Your Past Level of Dopamine affects your Current Level and this will again influence your Future Levels.                                        1. You have to take care/control/regulate on                                             the Present Level of your dopamine.                                         2. Practical summary:   1. Dopamine management - Abstain from or limit highly desirable activities for up to a month so the dopamine levels are replenished and the baseline dopamine release returns to normal 	- Peaks of dopamine decrease our baseline dopamine, required to general motivation and satisfaction with life. - Go for intermittent, random releases of dopamine 	- Don't bundle pleasurable activities with things you want to do (gym and music) 	- Flip a coin and choose how much pleasure bundling you'll do to the next activity 	- Otherwise the activity alone becomes less pleasurable  2. Direct practices - Cold water exposure - 2.5x increase and sustained for hours afterwards - Peaks 	- Chocolate - 1.5x 	- Sex - 2x (act and pursuit of it) 	- Nicotine - 2.5x 	- Cocaine - 2.5x 	- Amphetamine - 10x 	- Exercise - 2x (up to 2x, the more you enjoy it subjectively) - Coffee combined with another activity (coffee makes the dopamine release more effective) - Connection with other people  3. Mental strategies - Subjectivity, perception and belief 	- Hearing something that validates our belief about an activity, makes it more pleasurable 	- Journaling, thinking positively about something you remember or you're experiencing now releases dopamine - Learn to spike dopamine from effort 	- Don't spike dopamine prior to engaging in effort 	- Don't spike dopamine after engaging in effort 	- Learn to spike dopamine from effort itself.

Dr. Huberman, the odds of you seeing this are slim to none, since this video is almost a year old now, but thank you for this. For the last several months, I've done exactly what you spoke about - engaging in constant excessive dopamine inducing pleasantries (smoking weed, video games, being glued to my phone, etc.) and I've never felt more depressed and unmotivated in my life, despite my external circumstances being privileged and comfortable. I even began to think I had undiagnosed ADHD, but after this video I'm certain I just have a very depleted pool of baseline dopamine. I'm on day 2 of my detox, no marijuana, videogames only after work and not late at night, minimal phone screen time, and it's like you said - very difficult, but I intend to stick to it because I need to regain control of my life. The way you convey scientific information and then follow up with real world examples and applications is nothing short of eloquent, and I'm sincerely grateful for your knowledge and insight. Thanks again.

Â @yac7571Â  Someone else answered about the (purported) difference with cold water exposure, but with regards to something like exercise: what he was saying is that you want to avoid extraordinarily large dopamine peaks that will undermine your ability to benefit from normal dopamine peaks, which you get from something like exercise (if you enjoy exercise). It is good to experience the normal dynamic variance of dopamine levels because that is what the system has evolved to do to benefit us. But regularly using or indulging abnormal/unnatural/external sources of dopamine spiking will mess with your perception of other normal things in the short term and degrade your baseline and overall life satisfaction in the long term. He also didn't say to totally abstain from chocolate either - just be aware of how it affects your dopamine and enjoy it accordingly.

I will not take ANY drugs these days and certainly not the toxic vaxx.  I am not anti-science.  I am anti-stupid.

MDMA and amphetamines are analogs of PEA and were synthetically designed by tweaking the PEA molecule. PEA is your endogenous amphetamine. Hence they are called phenylethylamines. Phenylethylamines don't have a receptor but they have many effects on many different receptors and monoamine transporters. Reversing dopamine and serotonin reuptake transporters to release more instead of reuptake. Also have many effects on the receptors themselves in many different ways.  PEA is rapidly metabolised rapidly and barely measurable but amphetamines and MDMA and other analogs have way longer half lives. Comment for souces.

My Dopamine Experience  00:36:58 Tool 3 Controlling Dopamine Peaks & Baselines 00:40:06 Chocolate, Sex (Pursuit & Behavior), Nicotine, Cocaine, Amphetamine, Exercise 00:46:46 Tool 4 Caffeine Increases Dopamine Receptors 00:49:54 Pursuit, Excitement & Your â€œDopamine Setpointâ€ 00:56:46 Your Pleasure-Pain Balance & Defining â€œPainâ€ 01:00:00 Addiction, Dopamine Depletion, & Replenishing Dopamine 01:07:50 Tool 5 Ensure Your Best (Healthy) Dopamine Release 01:15:28 Smart Phones: How They Alter Our Dopamine Circuits 01:19:45 Stimulants & Spiking Dopamine: Counterproductive for Work, Exercise & Attention 01:22:20 Caffeine Sources Matter: Yerba Mate & Dopamine Neuron Protection 01:24:20 Caffeine & Neurotoxicity of MDMA 01:26:15 Amphetamine, Cocaine & Detrimental Rewiring of Dopamine Circuits 01:27:57 Ritalin, Adderall, (Ar)Modafinil: ADHD versus non-Prescription Uses 01:28:45 Tool 6 Stimulating Long-Lasting Increases in Baseline Dopamine  01:37:55 Tool 7 Tuning Your Dopamine for Ongoing Motivation ğŸ”¥!!  1:38:20 Hard work is hard. Generally, most people don't like working hard. Some people do, but most people work hard in order to achieve some end goal. End goals are terrific and rewards are terrific whether or not they are monetary social or any kind. However, because of the way that dopamine relates to our perception of time, working hard at something for sake of a reward that comes afterward, can make the hard work much more challenging and make us much less likely to lean into hard work in the future.  1:41:43 My colleague at Stanford, Carol Dweck, as many of you know, has come up with this incredible theory and principle, and actually goes beyond theory and principle called   "Growth Mindset", which is this striving to be better to be in this mindset of I'm not there yet, but striving itself is the end goal.  And that of course delivers you to tremendous performance. It's been observed over and over and over again, that people that have growth mindset, kids that have growth mindset end up performing very well because they're focused on the effort itself.  And all of us can cultivate growth mindset. The neural mechanism of cultivating growth mindset involves learning to access the rewards from effort and doing. And that's hard to do because you have to engage this prefrontal component of the mesolimbic circuit. You have to tell yourself, okay, this effort is great, this effort is pleasureful.  Even though you might actually be in a state of physical pain from the exercise, or I can recall this from college, just feeling like I wanted to get up from my desk, but forcing myself to study, forcing myself and forcing myself.   What you find over time is that you can start to associate a dopamine release.  You can evoke dopamine release from the friction and the challenge that you happen to be in. You completely eliminate the ability to generate those circuits and the rewarding process of being able to reward friction while in effort, if you are focused only on the goal that comes at the end. Because of the way that dopamine marks time.  So if you say, oh, I'm going to do this very hard thing, and I'm going to push and push and push and push for that end goal that comes later.  Not only do you enjoy the process of what you're doing less, you actually make it more painful while you're engaging in it.  You make yourself less efficient at it, because if you were able to access dopamine while in effort, dopamine has all these incredible properties of increasing the amount of energy in our body, and in our mind, our ability to focus by way of dopamines conversion into epinephrin. But also you're undermining your ability to lean back into that activity the next time.  The next time you need twice as much coffee and three times as much loud music, and four times as much energy drink and the social connection just to get out the door in order to do the run or to study. So what's more beneficial in fact can serve as a tremendous amplifier on all endeavors that you engage in. Especially hard endeavors is to A, not start layering in other sources of dopamine in order to get to the starting line, not layering in other sources of dopamine in order to be able to continue, but rather to subjectively start to attach the feeling of friction and effort to an internally generated reward system. And this is not meant to be vague, this is a system that exists in your mind, that exists in the minds of humans for hundreds of thousands of years, by which you're not just pursuing the things that are innately pleasureful, food, sex, warmth, water when you're thirsty. But the beauty of this mesolimbic reward pathway that I talked about earlier is that, it includes the forebrain. So you can tell yourself the effort part is the good part.  I know it's painful, I know this doesn't feel good, but I'm focused on this. I'm going to start to access the reward. You will find the rewards, meaning the dopamine release inside of effort if you repeat this over and over again. And what's beautiful about it is that, it starts to become reflexive for all types of effort. When we focus only on the trophy, only on the grade, only on the win as the reward, you undermine that entire process. So how do you do this? You do this in those moments of the most intense friction. You tell yourself this is very painful and because it's painful, it will evoke an increase in dopamine release later, meaning it will increase my baseline in dopamine, but you also have to tell yourself that in that moment you are doing it by choice and you're doing it because you love it. And I know that sounds like lying to yourself, and in some ways it is lying to yourself, but it's lying to yourself in the context of a truth which is that you want it to feel better. You want it to feel even pleasureful. Now, this is very far and away different from thinking about the reward that comes at the end, the hot fudge sundae for after you cross the finish line and you can replace hot fudge sundae with whatever reward happens to be appealing to you. We revere people who are capable of doing what I'm describing. 1:46:22  1:45:25 How to attach pleasure to effort: "In those moments of the most instense friction you tell yourself this is very painful and because it's painful, it will evoke an increase in dopamine release later, meaning it will increase my baseline in dopamine, but you also have to tell yourself that in that moment you are doing it by choice and you're doing it because you love it."  1:47:31 â€œDonâ€™t spike dopamine prior to engaging in effort, and donâ€™t spike dopamine after engaging in effort. Practical summary:   1. Dopamine management - Abstain from or limit highly desirable activities for up to a month so the dopamine levels are replenished and the baseline dopamine release returns to normal 	- Peaks of dopamine decrease our baseline dopamine, required to general motivation and satisfaction with life. - Go for intermittent, random releases of dopamine 	- Don't bundle pleasurable activities with things you want to do (gym and music) 	- Flip a coin and choose how much pleasure bundling you'll do to the next activity 	- Otherwise the activity alone becomes less pleasurable  2. Direct practices - Cold water exposure - 2.5x increase and sustained for hours afterwards - Peaks 	- Chocolate - 1.5x 	- Sex - 2x (act and pursuit of it) 	- Nicotine - 2.5x 	- Cocaine - 2.5x 	- Amphetamine - 10x 	- Exercise - 2x (up to 2x, the more you enjoy it subjectively) - Coffee combined with another activity (coffee makes the dopamine release more effective) - Connection with other people  3. Mental strategies - Subjectivity, perception and belief 	- Hearing something that validates our belief about an activity, makes it more pleasurable 	- Journaling, thinking positively about something you remember or you're experiencing now releases dopamine - Learn to spike dopamine from effort 	- Don't spike dopamine prior to engaging in effort 	- Don't spike dopamine after engaging in effort 	- Learn to spike dopamine from effort itself.

Main takeaways from me were:  1. Use your dopamine wisely. One way people use up all their dopamine is by layering dopamine activities e.g. watching football, drinking beer while scrolling instagram. There's a cost to this because you're going to create a massive peak which will take away from your baseline dopamine levels which means it's going to be harder to be motivated later on in the week.  2. Your rational brain can categorise things as rewarding/non-rewarding. This categorisation cascades down to your dopamine system. By valuing an activity for itself and practising gratitude for it, in the future it becomes internally rewarding. For example, if you rationally feel running is rewarding, it will become rewarding via dopamine.   3. Tie dopamine to the activity itself. Rather than use rewards (extrinsic motivation) learn to spike dopamine from the activity itself (intrinsic motivation).

Second time through I got so much more out of it.  It seems the simplest way for balance is seek challenge where failure is always a possibility regardless of effort (but success is possible), and seek new experiences more than favorite pastimes where you occasionally will love it and occasionally will hate it.  Simply put, without putting actual survival at risk like getting a new job every day or abandoning your family and making a new one every year, try to live life without knowing what to expect.     This has really changed my perspective in a positive way.  I do not really have an addictive personality or trouble with addictions, I occasionally drop alcohol, games, anything I think I may become addicted to for long periods (often 3-6 months) and often forget about them.  However, I do not open up to new experiences,  I feel like part of maturity is  having the wisdom to avoid failure, especially when others are depending on you.  As such I have a very controlled life.  I'm excited to put into practice how without being negligent or reckless and within those important controls (keeping my job and protecting my family/relationships) I can make sure I'm pursuing challenge constantly.   I can see a lot of room for expansion there.  It's easy to use life as medicine where you do consistent things for an expected result especially managing stress by watching your favorite shows, playing your favorite games, eating your favorite foods, hanging with your favorite people.   The risk of ruining your very limited free time is daunting when responsibility controls so much of your time.  My brain is exploding with this topic because I'm also seeing the connection to working too much and living for the weekend as it were, basically though, the goal is don't be a drone and you won't feel like one.  I'm going to come back to this video in 6 months and see how I'm doing.   Really appreciate this topic and your hard work.

It's important to acknowledge that "Dopamine" is just one piece of the puzzle. Consider how there are many high achievers who routinely violate all of these dopamine rules and do great. Many functioning alcoholics thrive in sales roles. Studies have shown they tend to do better than sober folks since they are more outgoing. Then there are low achievers who follow every step of this advice and still fail. I believe that "long term" success is about balance.   First and foremost, people need to be in somewhat control of their mind, body and lives.  That is foundational. Balance also includes being in generally good health which usually includes eating well and exercising. When this stress is reduced, it has numerous benefits which certainly include chemical benefits however my point is that we are not merely chemical factories.  We are souls first, followed by our chemistry- though if we are sick, that may flip real quick. Even the highest achiever won't be very motivated if they have a hang over! Chemical reactions are super important but so are many other things. Why is it that some thrive under high pressure situations and other crumble? Some people can listen to music, work out, then do work using two monitor screens and watch two videos simultaneously- both playing at 1.5x speed. Everyone is different so it is important to never lose site of the big picture which includes the entire person, mind, body and spirit.

â€œDonâ€™t spike dopamine prior to engaging in effort, and donâ€™t spike dopamine after engaging in effort. Learn to spike dopamine from effort itself.â€ - Andrew Huberman 1:47:31   So to recap..  1) Don't trigger dopamine all the time, even if gained through various sources. Try to dopamine fast.   2) Cold showers can raise dopamine without the crash.   3) Don't layer in dopamine raising activities with things you want to get more motivated for. E.g Listening to music while working.   4) Don't reward yourself before or after hard activities, let the activity itself produce dopamine.   5) Intermittent schedule of celebrating your wins. Don't celebrate every time and use a randomiser to dictate when to celebrate.  6) exception to the rule is caffeine (I.e coffee, tea) 1:20:00 1:19:45 Coffee good in moderation, Drugs and energy drinks bad  also 7) social media in general are bad because they basically let us waste dopamine that would be released in other circumstances. Pleasure and dopamine can basically become a conscious choice. I'm 60. My sister is 68. My younger sister is 52. NONE of us, including our mother when she was alive,  ever took a single dose of any kind of hormone therapy. They're chained in a standing only stall their entire lives, artificially inseminated, a tube inserted in their ureter to collect urine. Cation on the overselling of yerba mate and coffeine. It works like that on specific brain profiles but most people will experience a relatively huge dopamine rush and drop after. it can cause depression and even brain damage similar to cocaine and amphetamine. I am super sensitive and I crash similarly after a coffee than after amphetamines. I don't drink it - and I feel like people don't understand how green tea and caffeine is still a drug and a lot of "science" behind it is just industry-financed. It's a drug for the system we are in. If you want real longterm nootropic effects, or brain healing, neuroplasticity or anything in that field coffee or green tea is not the way to go. Lions mane and psilocybin for example and much more,...  "Accounting for all possible permutations, we consistently found that higher coffee consumption was significantly associated with reduced brain volume -- essentially, drinking more than six cups of coffee a day may be putting you at risk of brain diseases such as dementia and stroke."  It's obviously Andrew Huberman's takes are great but the one with yerba mate is bit random. I feel like it's his way of rationalising the fact that he still uses a dopaminergic drug.
