This is incredible...! I've been meditating for many years now, but only as of recently I've started using self-hypnosis to advance myself (and more specifically, to let go of bad habits). I've been using an affirmation of "My mind and my thoughts are always enhancing my self-betterment and my advancement in all aspects of existence". I do not really visualize the end result, but I focus this statement in my aura - basically programming the energy around my body (that also affects the thoughts inside my head) to act that way.  I know this can be considered "pseudoscience" but regardless... I had been following a drawing tutorial online, and PRIOR to starting self-hypnosis I had great difficulty with it! I would always take many-breaks in-between and feel very troubled by my inability to "do it right". And indeed, although I practiced a lot, I didn't see the end result I was supposed to see.  Now, two or three days after I started this self-hypnosis I noticed something that I did NOT understand the biology behind it - but I do now!! Actionable: 	- Cold showers can raise dopamine without the crash.  	- You cannot raise your dopamine level by lying to yourself but talking to yourself, being positive and finding and acknowledging what is pleasurable about an activity can certainly raise your base level dopamine. Also don't say I hate this but I love the reward I give myself afterward. 	- Addiction to a behavior can severely affect dopamine base level and won't let you be productive elsewhere  	- Dopamine system can replenish itself if you avoid engaging in addictive behaviors and your base level of dopamine may get back  	- Don't let an activity give you a very big high, have an intermittent schedule. Start paying attention to what gives you what level of dopamine release and start modulating it. Key is intermittent. 	- Layering different sources of dopamine during an activity can affect base level of dopamine, enjoy that activity only no music no phone. 	- Caffeine is good for dopamine receptors GPCR's (Chain bucket example) so caffeine is kind of the only exception.. 	- Remaining in a cold shower or bath by slowing breathing, dilating your gaze or try to get energized by leaning into the cold.   	- Forcing yourself to engage in hard work by motivating yourself and friction of that hard will become enjoyable over time because of rising in dopamine level during that activity and baseline dopamine in the long run. "Turning Effort into Reward"  Donâ€™t spike dopamine prior to engaging in the effort, and donâ€™t spike dopamine after engaging in effort. Learn to spike dopamine from effort itself.

With some caveats it seems dopamine could be understood as a neurochemical corollary to the old adages: Familiarity breeds contempt / absence makes the heart grow fonder. as well as the Seven Deadly Sins - if we sought to account for feelings of guilt or shame in purely neurological terms. Shakespeare famously refers to lust as "expense of spirit in a waste of shame'. But in principle conjugal love is biochemically identical: how we feel is always socially mediated. But that basic truth doesn't negate the value of gaining some understanding of neurological phenomena, which couldn't be explained more clearly than in this excellent video. Bravo sir.

Notes. -> There is no such thing as a "dopamine hit". There's a basline level of dopamine always in your body. -> Dompamine levels actually drop after you have a peak dopamine experience. -> There are two kinds of dopamine release tonic and phasic. -> Dopamine is not a neurotransmitter it's a neuromodulator. Difference: neurotransmitter is a chemical substance released by the neuron to send signals to the next neuron, while the neuromodulator is a chemical substance released by the neuron to alter the effectiveness of the signal transmission.  -> There two neural circuits for dopamine in your brain one for movement and one for motivation (drive and craving). The names of those neural pathways....i don't know how to spell.  -> The more you engage with an activity or behaviour and appreciate it, the more dopamine get's associated with it i.e your subjective experience has an impact on the rewarding (or non-rewarding property of an activity or behaviour)  -> Motivation and craving in evolutionary terms is foraging and seeking. Dopamine is a driver for us to seek things.  -> The Pain-Pleasure Balance: If you do or take something that rises your dopamine greatly (pleasure), afterwards you're low on dopamine (pain) because there isn't enough to maintain your baseline levels. -> But then if you keep exploiting that particular peak-dopamine activity to make you feel better again, you keep depleting your dopamine and thus further lower your baseline level...that's how addiction starts.  -> What is the healthy way to engage in Dopaminergic activities and substances: intermittent release of dopamine or intermittent reward schedule. Dopamine Reward-prediction error.  ->  Intrinsic vs Extrinsic Rewards. Associating the reward in the effort itself, rather than the end goal. -> Tip: Don't spike dopamine before engaging in effort or after engaging in effort. Learn to spike dopamine while engaging in effort.

Based on listening to this podcast, I have questions about doing hard work and not using external rewards for the motivation in the context of gamification systems for personal productivity.  These personal productivity systems are along the lines of Getting Things Done (GTD) or even just completion of simple checklists.  Which gamification mechanisms and to what extent can they be effective for long term productivity and which would be detrimental.  Examples of gamification mechanisms could be points for completion of tasks, assigning meaning by batching a group of related tasks into a "quest", acquiring a certain number of points (task completions) in order to get to the next level, leaderboards (competition amongst individuals), random schedule reinforcement for consecutive days spent working on tasks, etc.  Many of these could be considered external to the task at hand so this talk has me curious about whether gamifying work is a good or bad thing.

As he explained, the problem is not the release itself, the problem it's HOW it is released. For instance, if you release dopamine in a peak form using a drug, a lot of the dopamine being produced and stored in the vesicles of the neurons are going to be released to attend the request. On the other hand, if there was a way to release it in a transient way (with less of a peak during more time), the levels of dopamine wouldn't change that much, because there would be enough time to restore the levels during this release. This transient way of releasing is the cold water exposure, for example.  You should think that the body continiously produces dopamine to be stored in the neurons vesicles. Yes, it is a limited currency, because lots of things and behaviors use dopamine, even muscle movement, that's why the molecule has to be produced all the time, in order for us to live and move. What matters most, as I said earlier, is how it is released.
Â @tiagosillaspereira8590Â  so If thats the only difference, couldn't we produce like a retarded form of say cocaine or nicotine or microdose it throughout the day to have the same effect?

Â @kissenklauer7011Â  Yeah! That makes sense, there are probably some natural substances that have this long lasting effect on dopamine release, but unfortunately I don't any of those. In my opinion, I think that all comes to how much receptors of dopamine you have available, how sensible you are allowing yourself to be to the molecule. As Andrew said, to reach new heights in sensitivity to a substance you have to deprive yourself from it for longer periods.

Â @tiagosillaspereira8590Â  another thing that would be good to know is, does a higher receptor density mean released dopamine is "used up" faster, or is the dopamine metabolized anyway and the more you can make use of it while its circulating, the better?

Â @kissenklauer7011Â  To be honest, I'm not sure. One of the things that a high receptor density means is that the odds of dopamine to connect to the receptor are higher. So I go along with you, the more you can use while it is released, the better. Because if the cells can't "catch" it it will be recycled back.
Â @tiagosillaspereira8590Â  we need a selective dopamine reuptake Inhibitor xD

Hello Bruce, thank you so much for your comment! I have a question for you. I think I have big troubles with dopamine (phone addiction!) and struggle to be even a little bit productive. Even easy tasks are incredibly hard. Even when I start and push through for a long time I still keep quitting. I think this points to a big dopamine problem.  My strategy is to become very radical starting from tomorrow. (Gathering some more practical information today.) So far I have decided:  1. Stop using a smartphone alltogether, for about two months at least, maybe longer 2. Exercise every morning 3. Have cold showers every morning (I don't know which is better to do first - I think cold showers) 4. Eat some eggyolks and small amounts of coffee 5. cut out sugar from my diet (it really does make my brain foggy for between 2 and 4 hours!) 6. Try to actively enjoy the very process of hard work  Now, I finally come to my question! How do I do point 6 the best way? Here is my idea: Focuing on the friction and enjoying the friction so it evokes dopamine. How can I do that? Focus on how much I want to have that skill (I really do want it) and how great it is and feels to be in the process of building it up!  Do you think this will work?  Would there be anything in my plan you would change or something you would add?  Many thanks in advance!

Â @essennagerryÂ  Good on you.  I exercise first thing in the day, before ice bath . After the bath, although I'm very zingy with energy, but the cold seems to deprive me of good sustained energy level for running or weights etc. .Same regarding eating - better to exercise with good clean empty stomach running. In ancient times, we often had to run after prey, on an empty stomach, and had clearer head, etc. when hungry. Even in the for to eight hours after eating, I feel weaker and uncomfortable doing physical work. Digesting food is itself work for the body, in addition to the exertion - I'm myself new to the idea of cultivating 'enjoyment' of the struggle, the duress. BUT the way I'll do it will be my usual creation of visualizations about myself, and affirmations (declarations of self-definition that shape my self-attitude, and indeed, my very IDENTITY. I've already firmly defined myself as a person tough enough to ice bath every day, fast 16 hours a day, exercise almost every day, etc. I've created all kinds of images and videos that automatically appear on my PC background, telling me who I am. Who do you actually want to be? What kind of a person? Can you picture yourself like that? Do a Google to find images that inspire it, and if possible, past yourself INTO those pictures. 'Extremely powerful effect. - Truly, the ice bath, after 7 months gradually getting used to it, isn't that much of a hardship. I especially have used 'distraction' to reduce the suffering - I always sing a brave seafaring song, I focus on developing excellent diction (for public speaking in future) and being in tune despite some gasps that distort my breathing. I always also, though still also 'study' - think - what's happening to me, and use the discoveries to steer future events.  - I'm bemused by the smart phone habit. I would have thought you could set yourself policies less drastic. E.g. a chain of habit that only gives you an hour of it before you 'have to' do something else like going to work, or cooking dinner. Personally I use my PC all day long,  prob about 10 hours a day,. It's both serious work, constant crucial learning, and also fun like social networking, which develops my thoughts. I take good breaks - I set up a break reminder to happen every hour, and often obey it. 'Not addicted.  - I'm highly fired up by other activities like renovating, going out.

Caffeine increases dopamine effectiveness.  Give yourself intermittent dopamine (gambler effect) or let the activity produce intermittent dopamine. DO NOT chronically increase dopamine. Any such activity is doomed to fail. Only reward yourself DURING the activity intermittently. Use cold showers intermittently to avoid adaptation.  Don't reward yourself before, during or after the desired activity. The activity itself is the reward, supported by mental framing, thinking about how it helps you. Don't sweeten the pot with music, snacks or phone activity. Boy I sure love living like a monk! I am grateful and appreciative for every little thing that happens in my life. I also love God's cruel sense of humor. I say this jokingly, but at the end of a less luxurious day, a bitter chicory salad with olive oil, salt and herbs really tastes amazing.

That's actually not correct. And I don't see where he addresses it in the podcast other than maybe mentioning extreme schizophrenia cases. The reality is that there can be significant negative side effects associated with a high dopamine baseline.  The main ones being agitation (you get pissed off and agitated much more easily than normal people),  paranoia (you get super skeptical of the intentions of those around you including your wife (speaking from experience)),  anxiety,  and insomnia just to name a few. Don't get me wrong. I am a huge fan of DR Huberman. I just think that he paints a way too much  rosy picture of Dopamine in this podcast. I got done listening to the podcast and felt like my sole goal in life should be to go out and try to increase my dopamine baseline. Not true for MANY people. That's all.

Seems that Dopamin serves as the brain's and body's ressource allocation signal. An activity that is judged as being worthy is accompanied by high Dopamine level and hence promoted. Big wins are followed by a drop in Dopamine so that the body and brain can recover. Available Dopamin should thus be related to overall brain and body fitness and thus be increased by rest, fasted sleep or meditation. Prolonged periods of being unmotivated could also give the body a chance to recover.

Â @BE-tw9deÂ  I like to think about it in that your brain receptors are equilibrium seeking. Set the equilibrium high and it will be difficult to achieve it so you'll always feel low. Set it low and achieving it will be so easy you'll always feel fine, with occasional spikes of greatness that you have to allow yourself to recover from. The more dopamine you give yourself, the higher that bar becomes, which is why "dopamine detoxing" is so popular. What you're really doing is decreasing the intensity of dopamine release allowing the receptors to upregulate and keep your baseline at a better, more fulfilling level. Constant use of porn, sugar, video games, drugs, or even the more innocuous music, podcasts, etc. will bring your baseline down to the point where dull moments become unbearably dull. Waiting for your doctor's appointment becomes so boring you immediately jump to memes on your phone rather than sit quietly a minute or read a book. Reading a nonfiction textbook for class becomes arduous without music, a sugary latte, Adderall, and the promise of chocolate at the end because you've forced low dopamine activities to be high ones and now your brain thinks the lower dopamine state is abysmally low by comparison.
AMAZING RECAP!!!!!!!

Â @BE-tw9deÂ  Lets avoid "good" and "bad" and just talk about what would happen. So if you are very affective at convincing yourself that hardworking is rewarding you will get a spike in dopamine every time you work hard. The more friction you experience the bigger the spike. If you are getting big spikes all the time from hard work your baseline of dopamine will fall and you will crave hard work. When this goes further you will essentially be addicted to hardwork; you'll crave it, nothing else will be satisfying, and even hard work itself won't do much for you.  If you actually become addicted to hard work that probably means you're doing well in terms of accomplishing things, but you won't feel good. At that point all you need to do is take a break from hard work or avoid the feeling of high friction. From there you can try to find the right balance to maintain a high dopamine baseline or you can just accept that every once in a while you have to take a break. Â @jacobjanes6953Â  had the same question. if going to the gym increases dopamine then when exactly am I supposed to schedule it in before getting hard work done. Huberman says no dopamine before otherwise itâ€™ll make the work harder to endure. but then he also says no dopamine after because that would be associating dopamine to reward. also say I donâ€™t engage in any dopamine peaking behavior until after completing hard work, is any sort of action I do in the hours after (ex. use social media) considered to be a reward. what else are we supposed to do after and then when else can we just relax to use our phones or watch tv or whatever.

Â @jacobjanes6953Â  No dopamine before hard work (gym) because your dopamine will dip afterwards (while you're exercising). And not rewarding yourself after hard work (gym) is based on the logic that you'll associate the hard work (gym) with the reward, and not learn to release dopamine while working hard itself, our goal. So, try to not associate hard work with reward by not getting cheap dopaminergic hits afterwards, like using social media, watching a movie or TV show, masturbating etc. Instead, you can do things that are neither reward nor work, like making & eating healthy food after exercising, taking a shower (not too enjoyable, adjust the temp accordingly), doing dishes etc. Depends on what you find neutral these days. Then, after an hour or so, you can follow the same protocol of not spiking dopamine too much by adding cheap dopaminergic activities together, like in my case not watching an episode of a TV show, while checking social media from time to time (shut you smartphone down), not checking news, not drinking something with high sugar, not pausing it and opening a YT video in a new tab, not sitting in very bad (but enjoyable) posture, not chewing a gum, not replying to messages, etc.

I'm only 28 minutes in but I think I just understand why relying on motivation to do something is one of the shitties ideas ever. Obviously, it feels right: dopamine high -> we want to do somthething = motivation. But if you want to do something that you DON'T want to do and motivate yourself before than somewhere in the middle of doing the task you're going to feel lethargic and since chemical stuff is more powerfull than the pleasure of simply getting something done you're not going to feel satisfied by finishing your task. You're going to remember that you didn't enjoy finishing the task. And you're going to remember that it was very hard to finish. So the next time doing it you won't feel motivated to do the task whereas someone who only relied on dopamine from finishing the task will. So reapeat it for a couple of months and you'll just end up hating doing that task. Whereas someone who didnt motivate themselves before and, I don't know, let's say, studied or went for a run first thing in the morning, before he consumed food, coffee or nicotine, is going to enjoy not only finishing the task, but also staring it.   Anyway, if you read all of it, can you maybe give a little critique? Because I'm not sure I understand. Thanks!

Im sharing only my intuition after watching this video:: When you started studying while listening to music, you are more motivated. Because in the past you were studying without music and now you have additional dopamine and so more gap from the prior. So, few days or weeks later your prior dapamine is set to new level i.e. with music and you are less motivated compared to you initially were.  And one day you suddenly stop music and starts to study, now you dont even have that additional dopamin. And you are even less motivated to study than you were before you started to study with music. But this is temporary. It does not degrade your ability to study without music forever. After few days of no study or without music your dopamin prior level reset and now you can listen to music for more motivation. So, it would be better to listen music in random days while studying.

Great info except I'd query the caffeine advice. Caffeine is a psychoactive stimulant and suggesting dopamine receptors up-regulate with caffeine is only half the story. For that to occur you will need to consume higher and higher quantities, and then have the inevitable down-regulation during withdrawal. IN the exact same way as any other stimulant, such as cocaine or meth. In terms of finding good science on this, its worth noting that coffee is the second most traded commodity globally, hence skewed studies are rampant.

Well, well, well... Dr. Huberman.... you are literally saving lives.  How shall I encourage my GP to watch this podcast? He told me to cut down on my coffee in the summer of 2018. A few months later I was stressed and asked if I was losing my mind or had ADHD. He said simply, "You do not have ADHD, go see this psychologist." In 2020, after talking to a couple of psychologists, and me revisiting the ADHD again after months of reading about it, he sent me to a specialist. Yes... ADHD... I was given Vyvanse... and told to continue to increase it. When I said that I felt I needed a few days off from it every week, he told me that's not how it works and to take it daily. After a few months of the highest doses every day, I lost the will to live. Seriously. I was languishing.   I quit the med... Three days later felt better. FFS... But not as good as I felt before the drug.   I have asked for a small dose of Adderall and a small dose of Wellbutrin but was given Biphentin and told to increase that as needed.   NOOOOOO.... So, after more reading, I took a risk and took the tiniest dose of vyvanse and a tiny dose of biphentin, every two or three days and VOILA! A bit of help and focus...  I am both relieved at what I'm hearing in this podcasts and livid at my physician in this regard.

Dear Prof Huberman, just another quick comment, regarding huperzine A. As outlined in my earlier note on your eating disorders podcast, my physiology/neurology are not typical, but I wanted to share, as you mentioned you hadn't experimented personally with huperzine A. I was experimenting with nootropics about five years ago and obtained some powdered huperzine A, because I (thought I had) observed an especially positive response to acetylcholine. This was a microgram dose item, and I weighed it out quite carefully one evening but added a little extra. One of the worst nights of my life! If I hadn't been able to identify excessively activated acetylcholine, I'd have been really frightened. Insane saliva literally pumping out, extremely florid hallucinations, incredible nausea, shakes and sweats -- everything about it was extreme. I've never taken psychedelics, but this was like the worst bad trip I'd ever heard described. I was foolish enough to try again a few weeks later with a much smaller amount -- same results, just slightly less bad. Both times took a long time to recover from. Although an acetylcholine overdose was clearly at issue, I always wondered afterwards why it was so bad when I do so well with acetylcholine in general (and so very badly with any and all anticholinergics). Your mention of the implication of dopamine is perhaps the clue, maybe especially for someone like myself with bipolar/psychosis. I suppose this is a cautionary tale, but just wanted to share. Thank you again for your wonderful work.

Very good insights into how our dopamine and motivation system works. I am struggling understanding that part about trying to attach dopamine release to the process instead of looking at goals etc. I get what we want the result to be. If we attach dopamine release to the process, this will make us motivated to to things for the sake of doing them and that we know it is good for us. But how to actually accomplish this is a bit fuzzy to me.  So when we feel stress and pain and really don't like what we are doing, we shall tell ourselves we like it because it is good for us to try to somewhat trick ourselves into believing it? This part is confusing to me. My inner psychology don't seem to work like that. I cannot just logically reason with myself or try to fool myself to alter my feelings for something in some substantial way.  I think I somewhat miss the message here. I get that it is a good idea to get motivated by the process itself, like trying to find what is interesting in the process and the details you are learning and appreciate that you get to learn more. But when listening here, is sounds more like you should be in stress and pain and learn to like it? To me it sounds like that would take an enormous amount of energy resulting in some internal battle between two voices where one tells you it is very painful and the other one tells you it is good for you? This sounds like something that would ruin the focus on what I am reading totally if I am busy in an internal battle of conflicting voices.  The message here is a bit too abstract for me to really get a hold on. At the same time I really want to understand this because it seems to be really improtant for the motivation.  Edit :I have listened to that part of the video concerning this several times now. So as I understand it, one should tell oneself "The effort is the good part." so many times that we actually start to believe it internally. And also to realize that this is not actually lying to ourselves, since the effort actually is the good and constructive part even if it can feel a bit painful at the moment. When I think about it, it is actually our feelings of pain and resistance that is lying to us in the first place, so it is more like trying to tell us the truth.

I wonder whether the ways to increase dopamine to get into a flow state actually tie the dopamine increase to that exact process and NOT towards whatever process we wish to facilitate. Which could tie us to that process and hamper the transition to the desired process to improve.

So what happens to people who tell themselves a practice or habit is good, but it is not? BIG WARNING BELLOW! Yes they get the benefit of dopamine, serotonine etc but they are hurting themselves! Intermittent fasting is not good for everybody and to be proud of pushing our limits - in particular with comparison -  is more about a competitive serotonine than a motivating dopamine... You also see this use of "virtue signaling" in people who get extreme in the spectrum of the omnivore diet... If they do it while not needing it for health reasons, they need motivation indeed, but sometimes to the detriment of their health... Those practices are opposing the right somatic behaviour of listening to our body feedback!!!!  Social media is full of groups with intolerant people who use exaltation as a mean to not "drop off the wagon" as they say... So, as they are excited, I wouldn't say they freeze, but the parasympathetic blockage can also happen as a dissociation between body feedback and believes! So please be as careful with food as with cold therapy! Yes it is good to make efforts and feel some discomfort, if we have enough resilience AND DO NOT HURT OURSELVES. In the same way you don't want to hurt your body with an excessively cold water, you don't want to hurt your body metabolism with inadapted food choices!

2:13:45 re: control... now thats kind of a recursively conflicting notion of the locus of control -> "you control the dopamine wich controls you" but fine. And as for controling dopamine through pharmacological and non-pharmacological means, especially through supplements, if you have people monitoring the effects on their own systems through subjective perception, that seems like the ideal hotbed for autosuggestion. Im not saying that i dont believe that there are merits to this topic - given informed, responsible and reflective application - but when you go out and suggest to people to tweak or optimize somewhat obscure neurochemicals, lets be real here, we are very quickly leaving the realm of control and go into experimental, speculative or supplement-marketing territory.
